context: J. J. Thomson, the discoverer of the electron and a recipient of the Nobel Prize in physics, trained many physicists, among them seven Nobel Prize winners, 32 fellows of the Royal Society of London, and 83 professors of physics. This shows that the skills needed for creative research can be taught and learned.
question: Which of the following reasoning justifies that the argument does not depend on the assumption that scientists who go on to be the most successful researchers often receive their scientific education in classes taught by renowned research scientists?
answer0: the article only claims that many trainees were, not all of them
answer1: the article has nothing to say concerning general statements on where successful researchers receive their education
answer2: this is true, otherwise you couldn't make the claim that he taught anyone how to be a creative researcher
answer3: whether he was or was not internationally known isn't related to his ability to train creative researchers

context: "Good hunter" and "bad hunter" are standard terms in the study of cats. Good hunters can kill prey that weigh up to half their body weight. All good hunters have a high muscle-to-fat ratio. Most wild cats are good hunters, but some domestic cats are good hunters as well.
question: Why is it not necessary to conclude that a smaller number of domestic cats than wild cats have a high muscle-to-fat ratio in order for the statement to be true?
answer0: Domestic cats having a high muscle to fat ratio suggests that they are good hunters as wild cats that are good hunters also have a high muscle to fat ratio.
answer1: Cats could have a low muscle to fat ratio for reasons other than diet.
answer2: There could be other reasons a cat might have a high muscle to fat ratio than just hunting skill, such as medical conditions, being wild or a pet, etc.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.context: "Good hunter" and "bad hunter" are standard terms in the study of cats. Good hunters can kill prey that weigh up to half their body weight. All good hunters have a high muscle-to-fat ratio. Most wild cats are good hunters, but some domestic cats are good hunters as well.
main_question.question: If the statements above are true, which one of the following must also be true?
main_question.option: A smaller number of domestic cats than wild cats have a high muscle-to-fat ratio.

context: Ferber's syndrome, a viral disease that frequently affects cattle, is transmitted to these animals through infected feed. Even though chickens commercially raised for meat are often fed the type of feed identified as the source of infection in cattle, Ferber's syndrome is only rarely observed in chickens. This fact, however, does not indicate that most chickens are immune to the virus that causes Ferber's syndrome, since__.
question: What is the reason for why the fact that resistance to some infectious organisms such as the virus that causes Ferber's syndrome can be acquired by exposure to a closely related infectious organism does not logically complete the argument?
answer0: There is no indication that chickens have general exposure to infectious organisms closely related to the virus that causes Ferber's syndrome that would cause them to have population-wide resistance.
answer1: If it takes more than a year to show symptoms and chickens are generally killed within a year of being born, then chickens will generally never reach an age where they show symptoms, which would explain the rarity of Ferber's syndrome being observed in chickens.
answer2: Chickens eating a higher percentage of feed liable to be infected with the virus that causes Ferber's syndrome does not provide a logical reason for why chickens rarely exhibit symptoms of Ferber's syndrome.
answer3: Ferber's syndrome appearing in other animals that haven't eaten the feed liable to be contaminated with the virus does not have any relevance to Ferber's syndrome not appearing often in chickens.

question: Why is the attorney's argument not considered to be invalid due to the reasoning that having a violent character is not necessarily associated with the commission of violent crimes?

answer2: The attorney only says Smith didn't refute the testimony, not that he shouldn't be believed.

context: The new perfume Aurora smells worse to Joan than any comparably priced perfume, and none of her friends likes the smell of Aurora as much as the smell of other perfumes. However, she and her friends must have a defect in their sense of smell, since Professor Jameson prefers the smell of Aurora to that of any other perfume and she is one of the world' s foremost experts on the physiology of smell.
question: Why is the reasoning not considered to be invalid due to its misrepresentation of the position against which it is directed?
answer0: Misrepresentation is not the technique used here.
answer1: this has nothing to do with ignoring that preferences can exist while not actually enjoying either alternative very much
answer2: while it is calling into question to credibility, it's not calling into question the truthfulness of the opponent
answer3: the argument uses an appeal to the authority of the scent expert

context: Organization president: The stationery and envelopes used in all of the mailings from our national headquarters are made from recycled paper, and we never put anything but letters in the envelopes. When the envelopes have windows, these windows are also made from recycled material. Ttherefore the envelopes, and thus these mailings, are completely recyclable.
question: What is the basis for the organization president's argument not depending on the assumption that the mailings from the organization's national headquarters always use envelopes that have windows?
answer0: Sending mail from any specific location has nothing to do with its recyclability.
answer1: Whether or not the envelopes have windows is insignificant since the crux of the argument is about the recyclability of the mailings.
answer2: The envelopes and stationery were explicitly stated as being recyclable so it is not an assumption.
answer3: Being made from recycled material does not necessarily mean it can be further recycled after usage.

context: The Frauenkirche in Dresden, a historic church destroyed by bombing in World War II, has been reconstructed to serve as a place for church services and cultural events. The foundation doing the reconstruction took extraordinary care to return the church to its original form. It is a puzzle, then, why the foundation chose not to rebuild the eighteenth-century baroque organ originally designed for the church and instead built a modern organ, even though a donor had offered to pay the full cost of rebuilding the original.
question: How does the fact that an eighteenth-century baroque organ cannot adequately produce much of the organ music now played in church services and concerts help to resolve the puzzle described above?
answer0: If there was such a donation, it would not make sense to instead build a modern organ.
answer1: This could make the organ more appealing and desirable.
answer2: This provides an explanation as to why, with no barriers that the foundation chose not to include this one original aspect.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: English and the Austronesian language Mbarbaram both use the word "dog" for canines. These two languages are unrelated, and since speakers of the two languages only came in contact with one another long after the word "dog" was first used in this way in either language, neither language could have borrowed the word from the other. Thus this case shows that sometimes when languages share words that are similar in sound and meaning the similarity is due neither to language relatedness nor to borrowing.
question: What is the basis for the argument not requiring the assumption that English and Mbarbaram share no words other than "dog"?
answer0: That is not the case because both the two languages used the word "dog" long before they came into contact with each other.
answer1: The argument is based just on the word "dog", whether any other words are shared or not does not change the argument.
answer2: Without this assumption the argument fails because borrowing has occurred without the two languages being related.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.context: English and the Austronesian language Mbarbaram both use the word "dog" for canines. Thus this case shows that sometimes when languages share words that are similar in sound and meaning the similarity is due neither to language relatedness nor to borrowing.
main_question.question: The argument requires that which one of the following be assumed?
main_question.option: English and Mbarbaram share no words other than "dog. "

main_question.context: English and the Austronesian language Mbarbaram both use the word "dog" for canines. These two languages are unrelated, and since speakers of the two languages only came in contact with one another long after the word "dog" was first used in this way in either language, neither language could have borrowed the word from the other. Thus this case shows that sometimes when languages share words that are similar in sound and meaning the similarity is due neither to language relatedness nor to borrowing.
main_question.question: The argument requires that which one of the following be assumed?
main_question.option: There is no third language from which both English and Mbarbaram borrowed the word "dog. "

context: People cannot be morally responsible for things over which they have no control. Ttherefore, they should not be held morally responsible for any inevitable consequences of such things, either. Determining whether adults have any control over the treatment they are receiving can be difficult. Hence in some cases it can be difficult to know whether adults bear any moral responsibility for the way they are treated. Everyone, however, sometimes acts in ways that are an inevitable consequence of treatment received as an infant, and infants clearly cannot control, and so are not morally responsible for, the treatment they receive.
question: Explain why the claims above do not logically commit anyone to the further claim that if a given action is within a certain person's control that person should be held morally responsible for the consequences of that action.
answer0: The author mentions that infants cannot control the treatment they receive, but does not discuss whether or not infants can be morally responsible for their own actions.
answer1: The author's conclusion makes no assumption about a possible change in frequency of analyzing leader's deficiencies.
answer2: The passage relies upon the supposition that analyzing a leader's flaws is separate and distinct from looking into the flaws of the underlying institutions and procedures.
answer3: The author does not mention whether or not people should be held responsible for actions that they have control over, only that they cannot be held responsible for actions they don't have control over.

main_question.option: If a given action is within a certain person's control that person should be held morally responsible for the consequences of that action.

context: Health officials claim that because the foods and beverages mentioned or consumed on many television programs are extremely low in nutritional value, watching television has a bad influence on the dietary habits of television viewers.
question: What is the reasoning behind the health officials' claim that seeing some foods and beverages being consumed on, or hearing them mentioned on, television programs increases the likelihood that viewers will consume similar kinds of foods and beverages?
answer0: It isn't stated in the passage nor relevant to the conclusion how closely consumption on TV resembles that of consumers.
answer1: The claim centers on TV being a bad influence for unhealthy food consumption not the accuracy of health officials' predictions.
answer2: For the conclusion to be true it must be that consumers not only see food and beverages on TV but then follow through on buying and consuming them.
answer3: The claim is not dependent on how similar viewers' consumption preferences are to those on TV.

context: Mel: The official salary for judges has always been too low to attract the best candidates to the job. The legislature' s move to raise the salary has done nothing to improve the situation, because it was coupled with a ban on receiving money for lectures and teaching engagements. Pat: No, the raise in salary really does improve the situation. Since very few judges teach or give lectures, the ban will have little or no negative effect.
question: Why is Pat's response to Mel not considered inadequate for mistakenly taking the cause of a certain change to be an effect of that change?
answer0: As the motivation for the changes made was to improve recruitment of high quality judges, Pat should consider what effects the changes will have on such hypothetical future judges rather than their effect on current members of the judiciary.
answer1: No assumption is made regarding the ability of any current members of the judiciary being discussed.
answer2: Pat does not address the cause of the salary rise and lecturing ban, merely speculates as to their likely effects.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: The OLEX Petroleum Company has recently determined that it could cut its refining costs by closing its Grenville refinery and consolidating all refining at its Tasberg refinery. Closing the Grenville refinery, however, would mean the immediate loss of about 1, 200 jobs in the Grenville area. Eventually the lives of more than 10, 000 people would be seriously disrupted. Ttherefore, OLEX' s decision, announced yesterday, to keep Grenville open shows that at OLEX social concerns sometimes outweigh the desire for higher profits.
question: Explain why the fact that even though OLEX could consolidate all its refining at the Tasberg plant, doing so at the Grenville plant would not be feasible does not seriously undermine the argument given.
answer0: If the closing of the refinery would entail costly cleanup, it could be said they were still taking into consideration profits rather than the wellbeing of the local population.
answer1: The closure is discussed and the decision to not close is discussed, not the possible closure after the decision to not. If so and those employed previously at Grenville would be employed at Tasberg, this still would show their taking into account the needs of the local population as they initially wanted to consolidate Tasberg.
answer2: If the Tasberg refinery is more favorably situated than the Grenville refinery, the decision to not close would still be taking into account the local population and not profits and so does not undermine the argument.
answer3: The feasibility of consolidating refining at the Grenville plant is not discussed, simply its closure and if it were not feasible would still indicate higher profits from its closure and does not undermine the conclusion the company chose something more beneficial to the local population than for its own profits.

context: Heavy salting of Albritten' s roads to melt winter ice and snow began about 20 years ago. The area' s groundwater now contains approximately 100 milligrams of dissolved salt per liter. Groundwater in a nearby, less highly urbanized area, where little salt is used and where traffic patterns resemble those of Albritten 20 years ago, contains only about 10 milligrams of dissolved salt per liter. Since water that contains 250 or more milligrams of dissolved salt per liter tastes unacceptably salty, continuing the salting of Albritten' s roads at its present rate will render Albritten' s groundwater unpalatable within the next few decades.
question: Explain why the fact that salting of Albritten's roads is likely to decrease over the next few decades does not seriously weaken the argument.
answer0: If salting the roads in Albritten only raised the salt content by 10 milligrams of dissolved salt per liter in 20 years, it's unlikely that continued salting will raise the salt content to 250 milligrams per liter in just another few decades.
answer1: The benefit of salting roads has no bearing on whether salting roads will make groundwater unpalatably salty.
answer2: The argument assumes that salting will continue at the present rate, so changing this assumption creates a scenario that the argument does not cover.
answer3: The argument is around whether salting roads will lead to water that tastes unacceptably salty, not whether it will lead to water that is unsafe to drink.

Groundwater in a nearby, less highly urbanized area, where little salt is used and where traffic patterns resemble those of Albritten 20 years ago, contains only about 10 milligrams of dissolved salt per liter. Since water that contains 250 or more milligrams of dissolved salt per liter tastes unacceptably salty, continuing the salting of Albritten' s roads at its present rate will render Albritten' s groundwater unpalatable within the next few decades.
main_question.question: Which one of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
main_question.option: Even water that contains up to 5, 000 milligrams of dissolved salt per liter is safe to drink.

context: Heavy salting of Albritten' s roads to melt winter ice and snow began about 20 years ago. The area' s groundwater now contains approximately 100 milligrams of dissolved salt per liter. question: How does the fact that Albritten's groundwater contained roughly 90 milligrams of dissolved salt per liter 20 years ago weaken the argument?
answer0: The argument assumes that salting will continue at the present rate, so changing this assumption creates a scenario that the argument does not cover.
answer1: The benefit of salting roads has no bearing on whether salting roads will make groundwater unpalatably salty.
answer2: The argument is around whether salting roads will lead to water that tastes unacceptably salty, not whether it will lead to water that is unsafe to drink.
answer3: If salting the roads in Albritten only raised the salt content by 10 milligrams of dissolved salt per liter in 20 years, it's unlikely that continued salting will raise the salt content to 250 milligrams per liter in just another few decades.

context: Though Earth' s human population is increasing, it currently uses only a relatively small fraction of the supply of fresh water. Thus, claims that water shortages will plague humankind in the near future unless population growth trends change are simply mistaken.
question: Explain why the fact that the percentage of fresh water used for agriculture is likely to grow more quickly than is the percentage used for industry does not seriously weaken the argument.
answer0: The conclusion says that we’ll have shortages except if there is a change in population growth trends.
answer1: There's no reason to suspect that water usage rates in different industries are going to increase at the same speed.
answer2: This option suggests the possibility that we could have water shortages in some regions even if most regions have more than enough water. This presents a problem because many arid regions face water shortages even at current population levels.
answer3: This doesn't really matter. We're only using a small portion of our water, so water conservation doesn’t need to be a huge priority.

context: Mouth guards are increasingly becoming required equipment for contact sports. Besides the obvious benefit of protecting an athlete' s teeth, mouth guards also prevent concussions. Youth league referees should penalize teams with players participating without a sanctioned mouth guard.
question: Explain why it is not valid to conclude that the argument's main conclusion is that it is generally preferable to wear mouth guards while playing contact sports.
answer0: The author states that players not wearing mouth guards should be penalized, which suggests they think it's not merely preferable to wear mouth guards, but they should be required.
answer1: Mouth guards saving lives are a reason the author uses to reach their actual conclusion, that mouth guards should always be worn.
answer2: The author states that players not wearing mouth guards should be penalized, so it follows that they believe mouth guards should always be worn.
answer3: Mouth guards protecting teeth and preventing concussions are a reason the author uses to reach their actual conclusion, that mouth guards should always be worn.

context: When uncontrollable factors such as lack of rain cause farmers' wheat crops to fail, fertilizer and seed dealers, as well as truckers and mechanics, lose business, and fuel suppliers are unable to sell enough diesel fuel to make a profit.
question: Explain why it is not valid to conclude that farmers are not responsible for the consequences of a wheat crop's failing if wheat growth has been affected by lack of rain based on the information given?
answer0: The author is not assuming that there are not other agricultures that may be able to produce in other areas that could still support the economy.
answer1: Uncontrollable factors are beyond the control of farmers.
answer2: The author makes the assumption that when there is not rain and crops fail that others who benefit from the crop production will also suffer as well.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Frankie: If jelly makers were given incentives to make a certain percentage of their jellies from cloudberries, income for cloudberry gatherers would increase. Anna: That plan would fail. Cacao, like cloudberries, was once harvested from wild plants. When chocolate became popular in Europe, the cacao gathers could not supply enough to meet the increased demand, and farmers began to grow large quantities of it at low cost. Now all cacao used in commercial chocolate production is grown on farms. Likewise, if the demand for cloudberries increases, domesticated berries grown on farms will completely supplant berries gathered in the wild.
question: What is the reason for Anna's argument not proceeding by proposing a general theory as a way of explaining a specific market situation?
answer0: Anna's argument does project the result of growing cloudberries on farms by comparing it to what happened with cacao.
answer1: The workers who now gather cloudberries in the wild would not benefit from the fruit being domesticated and grown on farms.
answer2: Anna's argument doesn't contend that cloudberries are used for the same reason as cacao berries.
answer3: The fact that farmers began to grow cacao after it became a desired commodity is not general; it is very specific and could easily become the case with cloudberries.

context: Depression is a serious problem for residents of nursing homes. However, a recent study has found that residents who developed personal bonds with pets had significantly lower rates of depression than did residents who did not develop personal bonds with pets.
question: Why is it not appropriate to conclude that the best method for helping a nursing-home resident to overcome depression is to provide access to a pet based on the information given?
answer0: Not everyone gets depressed with no animal companion, so it isn't a requirement for someone's well-being.
answer1: While the passage says that having a pet decreases depression, it doesn't say how effective it is to other methods or that it is the best.
answer2: The information in the passage seem to indicate that people in nursing homes become depressed because they are lonely.
answer3: The passage says that pets reduce depression, not completely eliminate it.

context: Cable TV stations have advantages that enable them to attract many more advertisers than broadcast networks attract. For example, cable stations are able to target particular audiences with 24-hour news, sports, or movies, whereas broadcast networks must offer a variety of programming. Cable can also offer lower advertising rates than any broadcast network can, because it is subsidized by viewers through subscriber fees. Additionally, many cable stations have expanded worldwide with multinational programming.
question: Why do the statements not provide support for the claim that some advertisers prefer to have the opportunity to address a worldwide audience?
answer0: This supports the main point of the passage because we are told that cable TV stations have expanded worldwide with multinational programming.
answer1: This supports the main point of the passage because we are told that cable TV stations are able to offer lower advertising costs than broadcast networks.
answer2: This supports the main point of the passage because providing 24-hour news programming is an advantage for cable TV stations over broadcast networks which must provide variety.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.context: Cable TV stations have advantages that enable them to attract many more advertisers than broadcast networks attract. main_question.option: Some advertisers prefer to have the opportunity to address a worldwide audience.

context: Company Spokesperson: This year, more than 70% of the guests who stayed with us over the past summer are planning to return to our resorts for a summer vacation. Ttherefore, I believe that we are well-positioned for another strong and profitable quarter. Industry Analyst: This is not necessarily true. Nearly three quarters of the company's profits come from the attendance of its theme parks located at its major resorts, and it is not certain how this segment will perform this summer.
question: Explain why the statement that the company's management possesses more accurate financial information than is accessible to industry analysts does not support the criticism of the Industry Analyst?
answer0: Importance of operations plays no part in the actual numbers as to how many people will end up visiting the park.
answer1: Whether or not the analyst is working for a firm that is affiliated with the company plays no bearing upon his or her criticism.
answer2: Who in the scenario possesses the most accurate financial information does not play a role in whether the criticism of the Industry Analyst is supported or not.
answer3: This supports the criticism of the Industry Analyst because it would suggest that these returning guests will more than likely not visit the theme parks since they have already done so.

answer1: Importance of operations plays no part in the actual numbers as to how many people will end up visiting the park.
answer2: Who in the scenario possesses the most accurate financial information does not play a role in whether the criticism of the Industry Analyst is supported or not.
answer3: This supports the criticism of the Industry Analyst because it would suggest that these returning guests will more than likely not visit the theme parks since they have already done so.

context: Bacteria from food can survive for several days on the surface of plastic cutting boards, but bacteria can penetrate wooden cutting boards almost immediately, leaving the surface free of contamination. Ttherefore, wooden cutting boards, unlike plastic cutting boards, need not be washed in order to prevent their contaminating food that is cut on them; wiping them off to remove food debris is sufficient.
question: What is the reasoning behind the argument depending on the assumption that bacteria that penetrate into wooden cutting boards do not reemerge on the surface after the cutting boards have been used?
answer0: If the bacteria that has sunken into the wood can find its way back to the surface, then one would have to take more drastic measures to keep the cutting boards safe for use.
answer1: The passage is comparing the state of the unwashed boards to each other, so whether washing the plastic boards removes the bacteria or not is relevant.
answer2: The article is comparing the behavior of the boards if one just wipes of surface debris, so what happens to washed wooden boards is not relevant.
answer3: The article doesn't make the claim that wooden boards have no other benefits. It mainly specifies one benefit.

context: A commonly held belief is that cracking one' s knuckles causes arthritis. But this is, in fact, false, as indicated by the fact that most people with arthritis never cracked their knuckles.
question: Why is the reasoning not considered to be invalid due to the argument's conclusion that knuckle-cracking does not cause arthritis by appealing to an applicable principle?
answer0: There is a difference between the two groups of people as one engages in a behavior and the other does not
answer1: Just because those spoken with/sampled with arthritis claimed to not have cracked their knuckles does not mean that cracking knuckles never causes arthritis.
answer2: If appealing to an applicable principle, this would not indicate a flaw in the argument
answer3: If arthritis is caused by genetic factors, this would provide more evidence against it being caused by cracking knuckles and so would not present a flaw

context: During the past year, Pro-Tect Insurance Company' s total payout on car-theft claims has been larger than the company can afford to sustain. Pro-Tect cannot reduce the number of car-theft policies it carries, so it cannot protect itself against continued large payouts that way. Ttherefore, Pro-Tect has decided to offer a discount to holders of car-theft policies whose cars have antitheft devices. Many policyholders will respond to the discount by installing such devices, since the amount of the discount will within two years typically more than cover the cost of installation. Thus, because cars with antitheft devices are rarely stolen, Pro-Tect' s plan is likely to reduce its annual payouts.
question: Why is it not accurate to say that the two portions in boldface play the roles of a development that the argument seeks to explain and a prediction the argument makes in support of the explanation it offers?
answer0: the argument deals primarily with making a classification for a whole category of different things based off of one particular member of the category, so this is true
answer1: The possibility that antitheft devices will reduce payouts is a prediction, but the fact that Pro-Tect cannot reduce the number of policies it carries is not a development the argument is seeking to explain, but a problem that it is trying to solve.
answer2: the argument doesn't deal primarily with basing a classification off an unrelated type of organism
answer3: The problem is that Pro-Tect cannot reduce the number of policies that it carries, and the judgment reached is that antitheft devices will reduce annual payouts.

context: Auto industry executive: Statistics show that cars that were built smaller after 1977 to make them more fuel-efficient had a higher incidence of accident-related fatalities than did their earlier, larger counterparts. For this reason we oppose recent guidelines that would require us to produce cars with higher fuel efficiency.
question: How does the fact that new computerized fuel systems can enable large cars to meet fuel efficiency standards established by the recent guidelines constitute the strongest objection to the executive's argument?
answer0: Even if smaller cars can be made to be more fuel efficient, larger cars have been found to be safer so the advancement of the technology in larger cars is more likely to reduce fatalities.
answer1: The decline of fuel economy does not change whether or not both large and small cars can be made to be fuel efficient.
answer2: large cars being frequently involved in serious accidents does not suggest that they are not safer, or occurring at a faster rate than in small cars.
answer3: If large cars can be made more fuel efficient and be larger it would not be necessary to base car production on size in order to promote safety since large cars could be more efficient the same as smaller ones.

context: From 1980 to 1989, total consumption of fish in the country of Jurania increased by 4. 5 percent, and total consumption of poultry products there increased by 9. 0 percent. During the same period, the population of Jurania increased by 6 percent, in part due to immigration to Jurania from other countries in the region.
question: What evidence supports the claim that per capita consumption of fish in Jurania was lower in 1989 than in 1980 on the basis of them?
answer0: It is not known which specific people in Jurania ate which food so it's possible that immigrants ate more fish than other people.
answer1: From 1980 to 1989 consumption of fish increased by 4.5 percent but the population increased by 6 percent so the population increase is greater that the consumption of fish increase.
answer2: Although the increase for the consumption of poultry was twice as much as the increase for the consumption of fish the actual total amount of each food type consumed is not known.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Almost all microbe species live together in dense, interdependent communities, supporting the environment for each other, and regulating the population balances for their different species through a complex system of chemical signals. For this reason, it is currently impossible to cultivate any one such species in isolation. Thus, microbiologists lack complete knowledge of most microbe species.

answer3: We are not given information concerning reproduction of environmental supports and cannot assume that is the case given the information in the passage.

context: Fluoride enters a region' s groundwater when rain dissolves fluoride-bearing minerals in the soil. answer2: Even if the sources of the fluoride is varied, the source does not matter if sodium causes that fluoride to be dissolved in groundwater.

context: Brianna: It would have been better to buy a tree last summer rather than this summer. The one we bought this summer is struggling to survive this summer' s drought. If we had bought one last summer, it would have been able to survive this summer' s drought, because last summer' s normal rainfall would have enabled it to develop established roots. Trees with established roots can better withstand droughts.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that Brianna's argument draws the overall conclusion that if a tree had been purchased last summer, it would be better able to survive this summer's drought?
answer0: Since it is argued that it would have been better to plant the tree a year earlier, purchasing the tree one year earlier would be required to follow this plan.
answer1: While it is stated that established roots withstand droughts better, the point is made that planting a tree earlier, or the time frame needed to develop established roots is necessary to survive a drought.
answer2: Purchasing the plant does not increase the plant's likelihood of survival but rather planting it so that roots can be established does.

context: Striking newspaper carrier: The fact that this subscriber canceled her newspaper subscription is a triumph for the striking workers. It shows that the subscriber supports the striking worker' s claim that they are not getting paid enough. Newspaper company X' s president: That is ridiculous! The canceled subscription does not mean that the subscriber supports the striking workers. The subscription was canceled because the subscriber has said she does not read the newspaper every day and the subscriber prefers another newspaper. Ttherefore, the canceled subscription had nothing to do with supporting your strike.
question: Why is the reasoning in newspaper company X's president's argument considered flawed for overlooking the possibility that the subscriber's proffered reasons for canceling her subscription may themselves show support for the striking workers?
answer0: The passage offers an explanation for the newspaper subscription cancellation but does not use an analogy.
answer1: In the passage the president does not concede any point and instead dismisses the opponent's case in it's entirety.
answer2: The president does not fail to consider the subscriber cancelling to support striking workers but dismisses it out of hand.
answer3: The company's president ignores the possibility that the reason given for cancellation can also be congruent or in line with supporting striking workers as well since preferring another newspaper can be interpreted logically in this manner.

context: Sparva, unlike Treland' s other provinces, requires automobile insurers to pay for any medical treatment sought by someone who has been involved in an accident; in the other provinces, insurers pay for nonemergency treatment only if they preapprove the treatment. Clearly, Sparva' s less restrictive policy must be the explanation for the fact that altogether insurers there pay for far more treatments after accidents than insurers in other provinces, even though Sparva does not have the largest population.
question: Why does the fact that fewer insurance companies operate in Sparva than in any other province not strengthen the argument?
answer0: Cost of medical expenses has nothing to do with who would be bearing the cost so this option is not relevant.
answer1: If there are fewer accidents then this would ultimately mean that insurers need to pay less from their pocket.
answer2: Few options weaken the argument (since this indicates a monopoly).
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Hillsburgh and Nansensville are two major metropolitan areas only 50 miles apart. Until recently, the only road connecting the two cities was a traffic-clogged, six-lane Interstate Highway. Six years in the making, the Metro Expressway, a four-lane road connecting the two cities, was hoped to relieve this congestion. After the first month, however, the traffic along the Interstate Highway has not improved.
question: Why does the fact that the Hillsburgh Gazette reports that police activity along the Interstate Highway has decreased since many police are now patrolling the Metro Expressway not account for the continued traffic congestion along the Interstate Highway?
answer0: How the road is patrolled does not imply why it is or is not being used.
answer1: There are other reasons, like price, that would drive a person to prefer one cabinet maker over the other.
answer2: They type of wood used would not effect quality in the making of the cabinets.
answer3: A lack of transportation that is commonly used being unavailable is likely to have an impact on how each path of travel is used.

context: Offshore oil-drilling operations entail an unavoidable risk of an oil spill, but importing oil on tankers presently entails an even greater such risk per barrel of oil. Ttherefore, if we are to reduce the risk of an oil spill without curtailing our use of oil, we must invest more in offshore operations and import less oil on tankers.
question: How does the fact that tankers can easily be redesigned so that their use entails less risk of an oil spill weaken the argument?
answer0: The argument concerns only the risks of oil spills, not damage to the ocean floor.
answer1: The argument is concerned only with preventing oil spills, not the relative costs of methods of oil transport.
answer2: Tankers being easy convertible to a safer a form of oil transporter would directly under the arguments assertion that they are too dangerous relative to an alternative means of oil importation.
answer3: Tankers causing more serious spills than drilling would actually strength the argument for investing more in drilling, as it would reduce the likelihood of a serious spill.

main_question.option: Tankers can easily be redesigned so that their use entails less risk of an oil spill.

context: Researcher: Dinosaur fossils come in various forms, including mineralized bones and tracks in dried mud flats. However, mineralized dinosaur bones and dinosaur tracks in dried mud flats are rarely found together. This isn' t surprising, because creatures that scavenged dinosaur carcasses most likely frequented mud flats to find food.
question: Explain why the fact that dinosaur fossils other than mineralized bone or tracks in dried mud flats are quite common does not strengthen the researcher's argument.
answer0: This would strengthen the researcher's argument because it would provide explanation as to why the bones and tracks are rarely found together.
answer1: The researcher is only discussing mineralized dinosaur fossils, therefore other types of dinosaur fossils is not related to the researcher's argument.
answer2: Which of the two have been found the most or the least really has no bearing upon the researcher's argument that the tracks and bones are rarely found together.
answer3: Other areas in which dinosaur tracks are found neither strengthens or harms the researcher's argument that dinosaur bones and tracks are rarely found together.

context: Sales manager: Last year the total number of meals sold in our company' s restaurants was much higher than it was the year before. Obviously consumers find our meals desirable. Accountant: If you look at individual restaurants, however, you find that the number of meals sold actually decreased substantially at every one of our restaurants that was in operation both last year and the year before. The desirability of our meals to consumers has clearly decreased, given that this group of restaurants -- the only ones for which we have sales figures that permit a comparison between last year and the year before -- demonstrates a trend toward fewer sales.
question: Why does it not follow that the market share captured by the company's restaurants fell last year if the sales figures cited by the accountant and the sales manager are both accurate?
answer0: The same number of meals sold in 2 consecutive years during which the total number of restaurants in the chain increased by at least one clearly explains why the sales manager and accountant came to opposite conclusions about the popularity of their restaurants. The sales manager neglected to factor in the increase in the number of restaurants.
answer1: Market share is irrelevant to the question of why the accountant and sales manager draw opposite conclusions from the same sales figures.
answer2: The question is not about the quality of the company's meals, it is about differing conclusions from identical numbers of meals sold.
answer3: The argument is about the number of meals so price changes are irrelevant.

main_question.option: The market share captured by the company's restaurants fell last year.

Accountant: If you look at individual restaurants, however, you find that the number of meals sold actually decreased substantially at every one of our restaurants that was in operation both last year and the year before. The desirability of our meals to consumers has clearly decreased, given that this group of restaurants -- the only ones for which we have sales figures that permit a comparison between last year and the year before -- demonstrates a trend toward fewer sales.
question: What is the reasoning for concluding that, if the sales figures cited by the accountant and the sales manager are both accurate, the company must have opened at least one new restaurant in the last two years?
answer0: The argument is about the number of meals so price changes are irrelevant.
answer1: The same number of meals sold in 2 consecutive years during which the total number of restaurants in the chain increased by at least one clearly explains why the sales manager and accountant came to opposite conclusions about the popularity of their restaurants. The sales manager neglected to factor in the increase in the number of restaurants.
answer2: The question is not about the quality of the company's meals, it is about differing conclusions from identical numbers of meals sold.
answer3: Market share is irrelevant to the question of why the accountant and sales manager draw opposite conclusions from the same sales figures.

context: The only physical factor preventing a human journey to Mars has been weight. Carrying enough fuel to propel a conventional spacecraft to Mars and back would make even the lightest craft too heavy to be launched from Earth. A device has recently been invented, however, that allows an otherwise conventional spacecraft to refill the craft' s fuel tanks with fuel manufactured from the Martian atmosphere for the return trip. Ttherefore, it is possible for people to go to Mars in a spacecraft that carries this device and then return.
question: What evidence is there to suggest that the argument does not rely on the assumption that a conventional spacecraft equipped with the device would not be appreciably more expensive to construct than current spacecraft typically are?
answer0: The amount of space taken up does not impact the spacecraft's weight.
answer1: The fuel manufacturing source is not relevant or in scope at all.
answer2: Weight is the only factor that prevents humans from traveling but a device that fuels in the Martian atmosphere makes it possible for humans to travel. That means the weight of the device must be less than the tanks of fuel that a conventional spacecraft would otherwise need to carry.
answer3: The expense does not have any bearing on the actual weight of the spacecraft.

context: Several years ago, the number of wood bison became so low that conservationists began breeding the wood bison in an enclosed refuge. In this time, the number of wood bison has tripled and, according to conservationists, this number is enough for a species to remain viable in the wild. Yet since the wood bison's habitat is still imperiled, conservationists plan to move the wood bison 2, 000 miles away, where the American buffalo, a distinct species, flourishes. The conservationists predict that such a plan will allow for the long-term viability of the wood bison as a species.
question: What evidence is there that the conservationist's prediction is not called into question by the fact that no wood bison has ever been within 1,000 miles of the area in which the conservationists are planning to move the herd?
answer0: If there are resources for the American buffalo to thrive in an area, the wood bison can thrive there as well.
answer1: There may be many areas the wood bison can flourish which the wood bison has not been able to travel to.
answer2: American buffalo's territory patterns in the past don't effect the wood bison's population.
answer3: The conservationists predict that the species will separately flourish and not mingle, causing one or both pure species to decline.

context: Restaurant owner: The newspaper reporter who panned my restaurant acknowledges having no special expertise about food and its preparation. His previous job was as a political reporter. question: Why is it not valid to conclude that the restaurant owner's argument draws the conclusion that the newspaper reporter who panned the restaurant is a good writer?
answer0: Calling someone a drama critic if they have no training in theater is only an analogy brought up by the owner.
answer1: Whether the newspaper reporter is a good writer or not does not indicate whether they are a true restaurant critic.
answer2: The restaurant owner believes that the newspaper reporter is not a true restaurant critic, as he has no expertise about food and his previous job was a political reporter.

context: Since the 1970s, environmentalists have largely succeeded in convincing legislators to enact extensive environmental regulations. Yet, as environmentalists themselves not only admit but insist, the condition of the environment is worsening, not improving. Clearly, more environmental regulations are not the solution to the environment' s problems.
question: Why is the argument's reasoning not considered to be invalid due to its lack of evidence to support the presumption that reducing excessive regulations is more important than preserving the environment?
answer0: Keeping excessive regulations has not been shown to preserve the environment, as it continues to worsen over time.
answer1: If the environment would have been even worsen without the regulations, then the regulations could have still bettered the environment while it continues to get worse over time.
answer2: Believing that more environmental problems is not the solution to environmental problems is not an attack on the environmentalists themselves.
answer3: An absence of environmental regulations is not the only thing that could prevent environmental degradation, but rather hypothesized to be one of the things that could prevent it.

context: Area resident: Childhood lead poisoning has declined steadily since the 1970s, when leaded gasoline was phased out and lead paint was banned. But recent statistics indicate that 25 percent of this area' s homes still contain lead paint that poses significant health hazards. Ttherefore, if we eliminate the lead paint in those homes, childhood lead poisoning in the area will finally be eradicated.
question: Why is the area resident's argument not considered to be invalid due to its assumption that children reside in all of the homes in the area that contain lead paint?
answer0: There does not need to be children in every home that contains lead paint for the argument to be true but rather all of the children with lead poisoning would have to live in homes with lead paint.
answer1: The assumption could be true which would result in the conclusion about lead poisoning in children being true.
answer2: Lead could be found in places besides the homes such as businesses and other public places.
answer3: There is no indication that the statistics relied upon are unreliable in regards to lead poisoning in children.

context: Gardener: The design of Japanese gardens should display harmony with nature. Hence, rocks chosen for placement in such gardens should vary widely in appearance, since rocks found in nature also vary widely in appearance.
question: Why is it valid to conclude that the gardener's argument depends on assuming that in the selection of rocks for Japanese gardens, imitation of nature helps to achieve harmony with nature?
answer0: The argument doesn't reference Japanese values.
answer1: Expression of harmony with nature does not have to be the only criterion for selecting rocks as it can be one of any number of criteria.

context: A common genetic mutation that lowers levels of the enzyme cathepsin C severely reduces a person' s ability to ward off periodontitis, or gum disease. The enzyme triggers immunological reactions that destroy diseased cells and eliminate infections in the mouth. But researchers are developing ways to restore the enzyme to normal levels. Once that happens, we will be able to eliminate periodontitis.
question: Which of the following reasoning justifies that the argument depends on the assumption that a person whose cathepsin C level has been restored to normal will not suffer from periodontitis?
answer0: Even if there were other causes for low levels of cathepsin C it won't change the argument: restoring that enzyme to normal levels is necessary for eliminating periodontitis.
answer1: The argument does not make an assumption about the timing of the cure instead it says "once that happens".
answer2: Since it is the lowering of the normal level of cathepsin C that leads to periodontitis, restoring it back to normal would eliminate that gum disease.
answer3: Periodontitis is not the only gum disease, and the argument is only about periodontitis and its cure.

context: Algorpal Industries produces high quality pneumatic filters. For years, they have primarily served manufacturers of domestic agricultural equipment, and over time, this market has been decreasing. A consultant recommended that, with a minor modification, Algorpal could expand into pneumatic filters for biomedical research technology, a rapidly expanding market. The consultant argued that this single change could reverse a ten-year decline in Algorpal' s profits.
question: What is the reason for why it is not useful to establish whether the number of biomedical devices at any single research center is greater than the number of pieces of equipment requiring filters on a single farm in evaluating the consultant's recommendation?
answer0: the existence of even better alternatives wouldn't necessarily mean the biomedical device approach wouldn't still be a good alternative
answer1: If the brighter light from sunspot activity affects predators ability to detect and capture hares, this would indicate that sunspot activity is a causal factor
answer2: this wouldn't necessarily invalidate the recommendation if it were true, as there could be more research centers than farms that would benefit
answer3: If local weather patterns that can affect species' population changes can occur both in the presence of sunspot activity and in its absence, this would call into question the conclusion that the sunspot activity is the cause

context: Computers perform actions that are closer to thinking than anything nonhuman animals do. But computers do not have volitional powers, although some nonhuman animals do.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that it is necessary to have volitional powers in order to think based on the information provided?
answer0: The passage only refers to the current state of computer's capabilities, it makes no argument about what they can potentially do, whether they will ever be able to think the same as humans.
answer1: If computers can think but don't have volitional powers as the passage states, then clearly the former is not a prerequisite of the latter.
answer2: The passage states that some nonhuman animals do not have volitional powers, and computers do not have volitional powers, but that doesn't mean some other entity cannot have volitional powers.
answer3: If computers can think but don't have volitional powers as the passage states, then having volitional powers is not necessary to be able to think.

context: Computers perform actions that are closer to thinking than anything nonhuman animals do. But computers do not have volitional powers, although some nonhuman animals do.
question: Why is it not reasonable to conclude that the information strongly supports the claim that computers will never be able to think as human beings do?
answer0: The passage states that some nonhuman animals do not have volitional powers, and computers do not have volitional powers, but that doesn't mean some other entity cannot have volitional powers.
answer1: If computers can think but don't have volitional powers as the passage states, then having volitional powers is not necessary to be able to think.
answer2: The passage only refers to the current state of computer's capabilities, it makes no argument about what they can potentially do, whether they will ever be able to think the same as humans.
answer3: If computers can think but don't have volitional powers as the passage states, then clearly the former is not a prerequisite of the latter.

context: In an experiment, each volunteer was allowed to choose between an easy task and a hard task and was told that another volunteer would do the other task. Each volunteer could also choose to have a computer assign the two tasks randomly. Most volunteers chose the easy task for themselves and under questioning later said they had acted fairly. But when the scenario was described to another group of volunteers, almost all said choosing the easy task would be unfair. This shows that most people apply weaker moral standards to themselves than to others.
question: Which of the following reasoning justifies that the argument does not require the assumption that the most moral choice for the volunteers would have been to have the computer assign the two tasks randomly?
answer0: What the most moral choice was is not necessarily the standard for what the volunteers would have applied to themselves and others.
answer1: Even if some volunteers felt they made the only fair choice available to them, this would not always be the same moral standards that most people would apply.
answer2: If no volunteers who acted fairly in choosing the easy task thought it was unfair for others to do so, then they would be applying the same moral standard to others that they did to themselves.
answer3: If the volunteers in the scenario made more accurate moral judgements than other volunteers, then it would show that not all volunteers applied higher moral standards to others, only these specific volunteers.

context: A manager cannot extract the best performance from employees by threatening them with termination or offering financial rewards for high productivity. Rather, employees must come to want to do a good job for its own sake. One of the best ways for a manager to achieve this is to delegate responsibility to them, especially for decisions that previously had to be made by the manager.
question: Why does the situation described in the passage not illustrate the proposition that increased responsibility can improve a person's sense of how power should be used?
answer0: The passage gives a reason why it is better for managers to delegate some responsibility to someone else.
answer1: The passage does not say who should make decisions.
answer2: The passage does not make any mention how people believe power should be used.
answer3: The passage does not say businesses work best when individual self-interest is harnessed to the companies benefit.

context: Critic: Political utility determines the popularity of a metaphor. In authoritarian societies, the metaphor of society as a human body governed by a head is pervasive. Ttherefore, the society-as-body metaphor, with its connection between society' s proper functioning and governance by a head, promotes greater acceptance of authoritarian repression than do other metaphors, such as likening society to a family.
question: How does the fact that in authoritarian societies, the metaphor of society as a family is just as pervasive as the society-as-body metaphor weaken the critic's argument?
answer0: If the metaphor of society as a body is also used in non authoritarian societies, it doesn’t jeopardize the conclusion because these could be statistical outliers.
answer1: If the authoritarian leaders are searching for ways to maintain power, then this would prove that the authoritarian forms of government are encouraged by these metaphors.
answer2: The use of metaphors by societies doesn’t threaten the main idea of the passage because justifying one’s regime is a mark of an authoritarian government.
answer3: If the society as a family metaphor is just as prevalent in authoritarian societies, one cannot argue that the society as a body metaphor is more effective.

context: Hine' s emerald dragonflies are an endangered species that live in wetlands. The larvae of these dragonflies can survive only in the water, where they are subject to predation by several species including red devil crayfish. Surprisingly, the dragonfly populations are more likely to remain healthy in areas where red devil crayfish are present than in areas without red devil crayfish.
question: How does the fact that red devil crayfish dig chambers that remain filled with water even when the surrounding wetlands dry up help to explain the surprising fact?
answer0: If diners on stools do not stay in the restaurant after dinner as long as standard tables, then the restaurant would be able to serve more customers throughout the day as each would take a lesser amount of time.
answer1: Even if one of the taller tables takes up less floor space, the restaurant's seating capacity is not changing as a result and so there would still be the same amount of diners.
answer2: The author assumes that the red devel crayfish are also relying on water to stay alive.  If the crayfish are finding ways t adapt to survive than this will benefit the dragonflies as well.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Business Consultant: Some corporations shun the use of executive titles because they fear that the use of titles indicating position in the corporation tends to inhibit communication up and down the corporate hierarchy. Since an executive who uses a title is treated with more respect by outsiders, however, use of a title can facilitate an executive' s dealings with external businesses . Clearly, corporations should adopt the compromise of encouraging their executives to use their corporate titles externally but not internally, since even if it is widely known that the corporation' s executives use titles outside their organization, this knowledge does not by itself inhibit communication within the corporation.
question: How does the consultant's reasoning use the two portions in boldface to describe a strategy that has been adopted to avoid a certain problem and present a drawback to that strategy?
answer0: This option is only half right. The second bold phrase does not question the significance of the problem the strategy addresses.
answer1: The first bold phrase mentions the strategy of corporations shunning the use of executive titles and the second bold phrase mentions the advantage of not adopting the strategy.
answer2: The consultant is not explaining any phenomenon. He or she is describing a business strategy.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.option: The first describes a strategy that has been adopted to avoid a certain problem; the second presents a drawback to that strategy.

context: The Biocarb Company wants to build a sterilization plant to treat contaminated medical waste in a city neighborhood where residents and environmental activists fear that such a facility will pollute the area. Biocarb' s president argues that the operation of the plant cannot cause pollution because the waste would be sterile after processing by the plant. He claims that after exposure for an hour to superheated steam in the autoclave, such refuse would be far cleaner than food prepared in the cleanest kitchen.
question: Why does the president's argument not depend on the assumption that treatment by superheated steam represents the surest method of sterilization?
answer0: Treatment by superheated steam does not need to be the surest method of sterilization, it only needs to work well enough for the needs of the situation.
answer1: The president presents a counter argument to concerns about pollution hazards so it doesn't matter if others besides environmental activists have these concerns or not.
answer2: The president's argument hinges on the fact that waste would be clean after treatment so it is necessary that waste before treatment is not a factor.
answer3: The presidents argument addresses stated fears of pollution, so other arguments against construction of an autoclave facility are not relevant.

context: A study of 8, 000 randomly chosen adults in a European country found that 75 percent of those who consumed alcohol an average of twice or more per week over a six-month period suffered at least one cold during that period. We can tentatively conclude from this that consuming alcohol tends to increase one' s susceptibility to colds.
question: How does the fact that seventy-five percent of those in the study who never consumed alcohol suffered at least one cold over the six-month period weaken the argument?
answer0: The two compared groups of those that drink 2x a week or more, to those that drink 1x a week, may overlap, and cause difficulty in distinguishing difference between the two, since they behave in similar manner. A control group is needed.
answer1: Control groups are important in research, and if the statistics are the same regardless of drinking regularly, or not drinking at all, then correlation may not be causation.
answer2: These two groups that regularly consume alcohol, may both have the same symptoms of a cold in 6 months, because they are both drinking regularly, this would be hard to distinguish without a control group of non drinkers.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Professor Robinson: A large meteorite impact crater in a certain region was thought to be the clue to explaining the mass extinction of plant and animal species that occurred at the end of the Mesozoic era. However, the crystalline structure of rocks recovered at the site indicates that the impact that formed this crater was not the culprit. When molten rocks crystallize, they display the polarity of Earth' s magnetic field at that time. But the recrystallized rocks recovered at the site display normal magnetic polarity, even though Earth' s magnetic field was reversed at the time of the mass extinction.
question: Why is it valid to conclude that Professor Robinson's argument does not rely on the assumption that no other event caused the rocks to melt after the impact formed the crater?
answer0: It is not necessary for a word to be included in the dictionary for it to take hold in society.
answer1: The author is arguing that the impact did not cause the extinction, so the size of the crater has no bearing on his conclusions.
answer2: Many times a word's meaning is distorted by people when it passes into common usage and this would invalidate this method.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Forester: The great majority of the forests remaining in the world are only sickly fragments of the fully functioning ecosystems they once were. These fragmented forest ecosystems have typically lost their ability to sustain themselves in the long term, yet they include the last refuges for some of the world' s most endangered species. To maintain its full complement of plant and animal species, a fragmented forest requires regular interventions by resource managers.
question: Why does the forester's statements not provide strong support for the claim that at present, resource managers intervene regularly in only some of the world's fragmented forest ecosystems?
answer0: The forester doesn't say anything about how many of the fragmented forest ecosystems resource managers regularly intervene in. S/he only says the fragmented forests need this type of intervention.
answer1: Since the plant and animal species require robust forests for survival, if no one intervenes in the fragmented forests to make them robust enough, some of the plant and animal species will disappear,
answer2: The forester does not say the forest ecosystems rely on the existence of plant or animal species to sustain themselves. S/he rather says the reverse, namely that the plant and animal species rely on the forest ecosystems for their survival.
answer3: The foresters only says the intervention is needed in "the majority" of the remaining forests, which could mean as little as 51%. "Most" of the forests would mean more like 60-90%.

context: In the two years following the unification of Germany in 1989, the number of cars owned by residents of East Germany and the total distance traveled by cars in East Germany both increased by about 40 percent. In those two years, however, the number of East German residents killed each year as car occupants in traffic accidents increased by about 300 percent.
question: What is the reason for why the fact that after unification, many people who had been living in East Germany relocated to West Germany does not help to explain the disproportionate increase in traffic fatalities?
answer0: Being relocated to West Germany does not cause a disproportionate increase in traffic related deaths.
answer1: Traffic fatalities from other modes of transportation is not relevant to traffic fatalities in cars.
answer2: The small quantity of used vehicles would not cause a spike in traffic accidents.
answer3: Both the increase in number of drivers along with the lack of driving experience can explain the increase traffic accidents.

context: When feeding, aquatic birds known as phalaropes often spin rapidly on the water' s surface, pecking for food during each revolution. To execute these spins, phalaropes kick one leg harder than the other. This action creates upwelling currents. Because plankton on which phalaropes feed typically occurs in greater quantities well below the surface, it is hypothesized that by spinning phalaropes gain access to food that would otherwise be beyond their reach.
question: Why does the fact that phalaropes rarely feed while on land not strongly support the hypothesis?
answer0: This would show you that they need to spin to access the food, if they spun everytime they ate it would be hard to tell if the spinning was necessary for the far down food.
answer1: This passage has nothing to do with land, it is talking about the water
answer2: The direction that they spin does not matter in determining the reason for the spin.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: In the year following an eight-cent increase in the federal tax on a pack of cigarettes, sales of cigarettes fell ten percent. In contrast, in the year prior to the tax increase, sales had fallen one percent. The volume of cigarette sales is ttherefore strongly related to the after-tax price of a pack of cigarettes.
question: Explain why the fact that during the year following the cigarette tax increase, many consumers had less income, in inflation-adjusted dollars, than they had had in the previous year does not strengthen the argument.
answer0: Whether or not most consumers were aware about the tax increase on cigarettes would not change how consumption changes when the increase occurs.
answer1: If the reduction in smoking was driven by people having less disposable income, it would counter the argument that the tax itself is responsible for the reduction.
answer2: The variety of cigarettes on the market would not be relevant to whether or not a new tax affects consumption.
answer3: Information on the dangers of smoking is a major variable besides price that might affect consumption, so if that information was unchanged over the year, then the price with the new taxes is probably the cause of the reduction.

context: Medical school professor: Most malpractice suits arise out of patients' perceptions that their doctors are acting negligently or carelessly. Many doctors now regard medicine as a science rather than an art, and are less compassionate as a result. Harried doctors sometimes treat patients rudely, discourage them from asking questions, or patronize them. Lawsuits could be avoided if doctors learned to listen better to patients. Unfortunately, certain economic incentives encourage doctors to treat patients rudely.
question: What evidence from the medical school professor's statements supports the claim that doctors foster, by their actions, the perception that they do not really care about their patients?
answer0: The professor believes the scientific approach should be balanced with compassion, not totally eradicated.
answer1: Economic incentives are blamed for the doctors' behavior, however the lawsuits are based on the patients perception of the doctor.
answer2: By being rude and dismissive to their patients, the doctors would give off an uncaring attitude.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Naturalist: For several years, coyote have had a robust population throughout the Susquehanna National Forest. Over the past seven years, the Canic Chemical Corporation in nearby Harrisville has been releasing low levels of bromide compounds into the air and groundwater. Some of these compounds, in sufficient concentrations, are suspected of compromising the immune systems of young coyote. A recent study over the entire forest established that 30% of young coyote did not survive their first year of life. Clearly, the bromide compounds released by Canic pose a direct threat to the well-being of coyote in the forest.
question: What is the reason for why knowing how many of the natural springs in the forest derive from groundwater that flows in the vicinity of Harrisville would not be useful for evaluating the naturalist's reasoning?
answer0: The author only focuses on the coyote.  It fails to mention if the naturalist has looked into whether or not the bromide could have an effect on other mammals as well.
answer1: The author does not mention whether or not the water has been tested for other nutrients or chemicals that may be present.
answer2: Are there other water sources in the area that the coyote could be drinking from that are not near Harrisville.
answer3: A young coyote does not have a very strong immune system.  By looking at what percentage of healthy coyote survive to adulthood it might give you a better representation on the effects of the chemical on the lifespan.

context: Provinces and states with stringent car safety requirements, including required use of seat belts and annual safety inspections, have on average higher rates of accidents per kilometer driven than do provinces and states with less stringent requirements. Nevertheless, most highway safety experts agree that more stringent requirements do reduce accident rates.
question: How does the fact that the roads in provinces and states with stringent car safety requirements are far more congested and therefore dangerous than in other provinces and states help to reconcile the safety experts' belief with the apparently contrary evidence described above?
answer0: Replacing car tires would lead to increased safety which would not present a reason as to the contradictory evidence showing areas with more stringent requirements tend to have more accidents.
answer1: The length of the road does not provide explanation as to the contrary evidence.
answer2: This supports the belief that stringent requirement do reduce rates even with the apparent contrary evidence because it gives us a reason as to why the rates of accidents are higher and can be attributed to the roads rather than the stringent requirements.
answer3: This would lead to more accidents everywhere and driver confidence or overconfidence has nothing to do with stringent requirements.

context: Provinces and states with stringent car safety requirements, including required use of seat belts and annual safety inspections, have on average higher rates of accidents per kilometer driven than do provinces and states with less stringent requirements. Nevertheless, most highway safety experts agree that more stringent requirements do reduce accident rates.
question: How does the fact that drivers often become overconfident after their cars have passed a thorough safety inspection not help to reconcile the safety experts' belief with the apparently contrary evidence described above?
answer0: This would lead to more accidents everywhere and driver confidence or overconfidence has nothing to do with stringent requirements.
answer1: The length of the road does not provide explanation as to the contrary evidence.
answer2: This supports the belief that stringent requirement do reduce rates even with the apparent contrary evidence because it gives us a reason as to why the rates of accidents are higher and can be attributed to the roads rather than the stringent requirements.

context: Psychology researchers observed that parents feel emotion while singing to their infants. The researchers hypothesized that this emotion noticeably affects the sound of the singing. To test this hypothesis the parents were recorded while singing to their infants and while singing with no infant present. They were instructed to make the two renditions as similar as possible. These recordings were then played for psychologists who had not observed the recordings being made. For 80 percent of the recordings, these psychologists were able to correctly identify, by listening alone, which recordings were of parents singing to their children. The researchers concluded that their hypothesis was correct.
question: Explain why the fact that most of the parents who participated in the study believed that the emotion they felt while singing to their infants affected their singing does not strengthen the researchers' reasoning.
answer0: Physical effects on the vocal chords and lungs could reasonably be expected to effect singing in a manner perceptible to others.
answer1: Study only singing while alone cannot support an argument concerning the effects of having a child present while singing.
answer2: A study comparing singing to offspring with singing to non-offspring could support the hypothesis to some extent, but the lack of a proper control experiment (singing with no children present) would undermine the hypothesis that singing to children per se affects performance.
answer3: Self-perception of the effects of emotion on their singing by parents does prove that such an effect exists, as that judgment itself may be clouded by emotion, social expectations or other factors.

context: Although marathons are 26. 2 miles (42. 2 kilometers) long and take even world-class marathoners over 2 hours to run, athletes who train by running 90 minutes a day fare better in marathons than do those who train by running 120 minutes or more a day.
question: Why does the occurrence of joint injuries that significantly interfere with overall training not contribute to an explanation of the difference in marathon performances described above?
answer0: 120 minute a day runners would be expected to incur more injuries than 90 minutes per day runners, producing a negative effect on their training and subsequent performance.
answer1: If runners who exceed 90 minutes per day become demotivated, this would help explain the poorer performance of the 120 minute per day runners in comparison to the 90 minutes per day runners.
answer2: Adverse health effects increase with running time would provide a reason for 120 minute a day runners to perform worse than 90 minutes a day runners, explaining their poorer results in marathons.
answer3: If greater running length per day increased the ability to adapt to longer races such as Marathons, we would expect the 120 minutes a day trainers to show better performance than the 90 minutes a day ones, not worse performance as actually observed.
