context: Wife: The work of the artist who painted the portrait of my grandparents 50 years ago has become quite popular lately, so the portrait has recently become valuable. But since these sorts of artistic fads fade rapidly, the practical thing to do would be to sell the portrait while it is still worth something, and thereby enable our daughter to attend the college she has chosen. Husband: How could you make such a suggestion? That painting is the only thing you own that belonged to your grandparents. I don' t think it' s a very good painting, but it has great sentimental value. Besides, you owe it to our daughter to keep it in the family as a link to her family' s past.
question: Explain why the principle that gifts offered as sentimental tokens of affection should not be accepted if the recipient intends to sell them later for profit does not justify the husband's reply.
answer0: The advantage to the child the husband refers to is giving them a link to the family's past, and the only benefit the wife cites to selling it is to pay for their college of choice, so if the former is more important, it supports the husband's point.
answer1: The husband does not make any comment on whether tokens of affection should be accepted or not if one intends to sell them at some point, only that the painting does indeed have sentimental value.
answer2: The author does not state anything about promises so that would not be relevant to the husband's point.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Baking for winter holidays is a tradition that may have a sound medical basis. In midwinter, when days are short, many people suffer from a specific type of seasonal depression caused by lack of sunlight. Carbohydrates, both sugars and starches, boost the brain' s levels of serotonin, a neurotransmitter that improves the mood. In this respect, carbohydrates act on the brain in the same way as some antidepressants. Thus, eating holiday cookies may provide an effective form of self-prescribed medication.
question: Why is it not valid to infer from the passage that lack of sunlight lowers the level of serotonin in the brain?
answer0: That cannot be properly inferred because the passage only talks about increasing the level of serotonin in the brain. Lack of sunlight may leave the brain at a base level of serotonin rather than lower it.
answer1: That cannot be inferred from the passage because there could theoretically be many other forms of depression that can be treated more easily than baking and eating cookies.
answer2: The antacid reduces stomach acid in general and there is no mention of how effective each dose is at neutralizing acid.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Contrary to Malthus' s arguments, human foodproducing capacity has increased more rapidly than human population. Yet, agricultural advances often compromise biological diversity. Ttherefore, Malthus' s prediction that insufficient food will doom humanity to war, pestilence, and famine will likely be proven correct in the future, because a lack of biodiversity will eventually erode our capacity to produce food.
question: Why does the statement that human food-producing capacity has increased more rapidly than human population not play a role in the argument as part of the evidence used to support the conclusion that a well-known view is misguided?
answer0: It is not a hypothesis, it is the current facts and so is not presently false but the author feels will come to be false in the future
answer1: The remainder of the argument following this fact states that human food-producing capacity will likely shrink as biological diversity is compromised in human practices
answer2: Human food-producing capacity increasing more rapidly than human population would go against the conclusion that a well-known view is misguided if the author had not added the remaining information in their argument
answer3: None of the above choices

Ttherefore, Malthus' s prediction that insufficient food will doom humanity to war, pestilence, and famine will likely be proven correct in the future, because a lack of biodiversity will eventually erode our capacity to produce food.
main_question.question: The statement that human food-producing capacity has increased more rapidly than human population plays which one of the following roles in the argument?
main_question.option: It is a hypothesis the argument provides reasons for believing to be presently false.

context: Rail Executive: Five years ago we discontinued train service between Lamberton and its suburbs because low ridership caused total fares collected to be substantially lower than the cost of operating the service. It is true that recent population growth in the suburban communities suggests increased potential ridership. Nevertheless, since most of the newer residents own automobiles, restoring the train service this year would still result in serious deficits
question: How does the fact that recently there have been sharp increases in parking fees in Lamberton and in highway tolls on major commuter routes cast serious doubt on the rail executive's argument?
answer0: If the hours of service increased and the total ridership still did not increase, it would be even less profitable
answer1: If few people living in the area support increased funding for mass transportation, they are not likely to want to ride the train and so the argument holds
answer2: If there has been a sharp increase recently in parking fees and highway tools, it is likely that the newer residents would ride the train to avoid the higher costs of using their automobiles
answer3: If most of the new residents do not need to travel regularly, they would be unlikely to need to use the train

context: The tidal range at a particular location is the difference in height between high tide and low tide. Tidal studies have shown that one of the greatest tidal ranges in the world is found in the Bay of Fundy and reaches more than seventeen meters. Since the only forces involved in inducing the tides are the sun' s and moon' s gravity, the magnitudes of tidal ranges also must be explained entirely by gravitational forces.
question: Explain why the reasoning does not contain a flaw as accurately described by the fact that it does not differentiate between the tidal effect of the sun and the tidal effect of the moon?
answer0: Differentiating between the two forces which are claimed to induce tides would not establish whether or not this induction is the only factor in determining tidal ranges.
answer1: The argument that only the forces inducing tides can effect tidal ranges does not consider that non-inducing factors may also effect tidal ranges, by causing limiting or reshaping effects on the induced tides.
answer2: The number of examples given is irrelevant in evaluating whether or not a general principle can be applied.
answer3: The argument is concerned solely with tides, and not with other activities which may occur within the world's oceans.

context: Networks of blood vessels in bats' wings serve only to disperse heat generated in flight. This heat is generated only because bats flap their wings. Thus paleontologists' recent discovery that the winged dinosaur Sandactylus had similar networks of blood vessels in the skin of its wings provides evidence for the hypothesis that Sandactylus flew by flapping its wings, not just by gliding.
question: What evidence is there to suggest that the author's argument is not based on speculation about how structures observed in present-day creatures might have developed from similar structures in creatures now extinct?
answer0: No apparently contradictory evidence is mentioned at any point in the argument.
answer1: The author draws an analogy between known heat-dispersing effects of structures within one creature to similar structures with another, to suggest that their function may also be similar.
answer2: The author does not discuss the origin of structures in modern-day bats, merely suggesting that they function in a similar way to comparable structures in an extinct creature.
answer3: No mention is made of any earlier theory, merely of earlier observations.

context: Interviewer: A certain company released a model of computer whose microprocessor design was flawed, making that computer liable to process information incorrectly. How did this happen? Industry spokesperson: Given the huge number of circuits in the microprocessor of any modern computer, not every circuit can be manually checked before a computer model that contains the microprocessor is released. Interviewer: Then what guarantee do we have that new microprocessors will not be similarly flawed? Industry spokesperson: There is no chance of further microprocessor design flaws, since all microprocessors are now entirely computer-designed.
question: Why is the industry spokesperson's argument not considered to be flawed for disregarding the possibility that a microprocessor can have a flaw other than a design flaw?
answer0: There is no mention that a company acted differently from what is considered industry standard and in fact the standard is justified instead.
answer1: Assumes that computers cannot make errors which is required if using computers to make them is the method being relied upon to eliminate errors in design.
answer2: Only design flaws are debated and other flaws would be a separate issue not necessarily affecting the design flaw issue.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Company president: Grievance procedures should allow the grievant and the respondent to select a mediator who will attempt to work out a resolution. Grievances are costly and mediation could help to resolve many of them. However, beginning mediation fairly late in the process, as our human resources department proposes, would be relatively ineffective.
question: How does the fact that adversaries' positions tend to harden as a dispute wears on, making compromise less likely, help to justify the company president's criticism of the human resources department's proposal?
answer0: this would make late mediation less effective, so it strengthens the argument
answer1: Similar to the uncovering of unpleasant or harmful truths, research should continue even if there are negative side effects.
answer2: this makes the mediation process a less attractive option, but not less effective at conflict resolution
answer3: This example shows someone should not do something that has positive side effects whereas the principle is stating that we should do something even if it has negative ones.

context: In the country of Marut, the Foreign Trade Agency' s records were reviewed in 1994 in light of information then newly available about neighboring Goro. The review revealed that in every year since 1963, the agency' s projection of what Goro' s gross national product(GNP) would be five years later was a serious underestimate. The review also revealed that in every year since 1963, the agency estimated Goro' s GNP for the previous year--a Goro state secret--very accurately.
question: What is the evidence that suggests that the claim that the amount by which the agency underestimated the GNP it projected for Goro tended to increase over time is strongly supported by the statement given?
answer0: No actual GNP numbers or mention of increases was given.
answer1: The statement does not address impact.
answer2: It does not state that after 1995 there was any intention to mislead.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Efraim: The popular press continually advises people to avoid various health risks. Yet by seeking to avoid health risks, people inevitably become anxious, and anxiety, in turn, poses a major health risk. Thus, paradoxical as it seems, simply disregarding journalists' advice about reducing health risks is bound to pose less of a health risk than does trying to follow any such advice. context: Advertisers are often criticized for their unscrupulous manipulation of people' s tastes and wants. main_question.context: Democratic governments are unlikely to take a morally principled stand on controversial issues, because there are almost always groups of people with differing principles who strongly resist any policy that consistently adheres to any particular moral principle. Thus, the compromises that opposition groups force on democratic governments make policies about controversial issues morally arbitrary.
main_question.question: The reasoning in the argument is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that it fails to consider the possibility that
main_question.option: democratic governments appeal to moral principles in effecting compromises between those with opposing moral principles

context: Maria: Calling any state totalitarian is misleading: it implies total state control of all aspects of life. The real world contains no political entity exercising literally total control over even one such aspect. This is because any system of control is inefficient, and, ttherefore, its degree of control is partial. James: A one-party state that has tried to exercise control over most aspects of a society and that has, broadly speaking, managed to do so is totalitarian. Such a system' s practical inefficiencies do not limit the aptness of the term, which does not describe a state s actual degree of control as much as it describes the nature of a state' s ambitions.
question: What is the evidence that Maria's main conclusion does not accurately state that no existing state currently has even one aspect of society under total control?
answer0: Maria believes that all regimes only have partial control, but she doesn't say whether she believes that this state of things is necessary.
answer1: While, Maria believes that there is no society that is totally under control, that is not her primary point.
answer2: While Maria believes that a totalitarian society must control the people, that is not her main point.
answer3: Maria believes totalitarian is a mistaken term because it wrongfully suggests that it is possible to achieve total control over all aspects of life.

context: Politician: The cohesion of a society depends on its members' accepting a set of basic principles. When these principles are routinely called into question, the society begins to erode. Any society, ttherefore, that allows schools to present the society' s set of basic principles as simply one of several alternatives, with the suggestion that students may choose which to accept on the basis of the principles' worth, is inviting its own demise.
question: Explain why the fact that children are more likely than adults to question the wisdom of those who founded and shaped a society does not strengthen the politician's argument.
answer0: If individuals would not find the basic set of principles acceptable when given the chance to assess it, then individuals given that chance would be more likely to accept a different set of principles, causing members of a society to have differing sets of basic principles.
answer1: Establishing a criteria for evaluation has no relation to whether or not the set of basic principles already chosen by it's members is acceptable.
answer2: If people repudiate principles they believe they have not freely chosen, then presenting no alternative set of basic principles would also cause people to call those principles into question.
answer3: Even if children are more likely to question those who shaped society, adults are the ones who hold power in schools and are the ones who make suggestions to students.

context: Analyst: Any new natural-gas-powered electrical generation station needs to be located close to a natural-gas pipeline, a large body of water for cooling, and transmission lines. It also must be situated in a region where residents will not oppose construction. Our country has an extensive system of transmission lines, but our natural-gas pipelines run in the vicinity of only three of our large bodies of water, and residents would oppose any significant construction projects near these bodies of water.
question: Why does the analyst's statements not strongly support the statement that there currently is no natural-gas-powered electrical generation station near any of the three largest bodies of water in the analyst's country?
answer0: The director's conclusion focuses on those who are struggling academically, and does seek to prove a single cause for why those doing well in school are succeeding.
answer1: Some of the electrical needs are being met and will continue to be met by the existing natural gas pipelines.
answer2: The article states that there are already gas pipelines located near these three bodies of water, so it is possible for some electrical generation stations to already exist.
answer3: The director's argument perhaps incorrectly assumes that students will put effort into furthering their academic success in absence of sports participation.

context: Finnish author Jaakko Mikkeli was accused by Norwegian author Kirsten Halden of plagiarizing a book that she had written and that had been published 20 years before Mikkeli' s. The two books, although set in different periods and regions, contain enough plot similarities to make coincidental resemblance unlikely. Mikkeli' s defense rests on his argument that plagiarism was impossible in this case because Halden' s book has been published only in Norwegian, a language Mikkeli does not understand, and because no reviews of Halden' s book have ever been published.
question: Why does the argument in Mikkeli's defense rely on the assumption that nobody related the plot of Halden's book in detail to Mikkeli before Mikkeli wrote his book?
answer0: The resemblances in the book are said to be beyond what could happen as a coincidence.
answer1: Mikkeli is said not to know Norwegian rather than Old Icelandic.
answer2: If someone was unaware of a story it would be impossible to intentionally copy it.
answer3: Meeting an author would not be required to copy their work since someone could read a work without meeting the author.

context: United States hospitals have traditionally relied primarily on revenues from paying patients to offset losses from unreimbursed care. Almost all paying patients now rely on governmental or private health insurance to pay hospital bill. Recently, insurers have been strictly limiting what they pay hospitals for the care of insured patients to amounts at or below actual costs.
question: What is the basis for not concluding that even though philanthropic donations have traditionally provided some support for the hospitals, such donations are at present declining based on the information provided?
answer0: Since insurers are limiting payments to actual costs or less, there is no extra income to pay for losses from un-reimbursed care.
answer1: Philanthropic donations may help to support a hospital, but they are not the main source of income and have not been the primary way for hospitals to offset unreimbursed care.
answer2: Patients who cannot afford private insurance and do not qualify for governmental insurance fall into the category of unreimbursed care, which is something hospitals have always had to deal with.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.question: Which of the following conclusions is best supported by the information above?
main_question.option: Even though philanthropic donations have traditionally provided some support for the hospitals, such donations are at present declining.

answer1: While this may or may not be true, nontraditional energy sources are not mentioned in the passage and we are not able to draw this conclusion from the given information.
answer2: According to the passage, the United States economy grew by 33 percent during the time period while the percent growth in energy consumption was 0.  These numbers suggest that the economy in the country grew without consuming additional engery.
answer3: While this may or may not have been the case, we are not given information in the passage other than the numbers regarding economic grown and energy consumption.

main_question.option: The development of nontraditional energy sources will make it possible for the United States economy to grow even faster.

context: Politician: Some proponents of unilateral nuclear arms reduction argue that it would encourage other countries to reduce their own nuclear arsenals, eventually leading to an international agreement on nuclear arms reduction. Our acting on the basis of this argument would be dangerous, because the argument ignores the countries presently on the verge of civil wars. These countries, many of which have nuclear capability, cannot be relied upon to conform to any international military policy.
question: What evidence does the politician's argument provide to support the conclusion that countries that are on the verge of civil wars are unlikely to agree to reduce either their nuclear arms or their conventional weapons?
answer0: The statement that countries on the verge of civil war would not voluntarily reduce their nuclear arsenals is a supporting fact for why it would be dangerous for the politician's country to voluntarily reduce their own arsenal.
answer1: The politician states it would be dangerous to reduce domestic nuclear arsenals in hopes that other countries would do the same.
answer2: The politician argues that an agreement would not likely be achieved by voluntarily reducing arms, but does not imply that such an agreement could never be achieved.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.option: Countries that are on the verge of civil wars are unlikely to agree to reduce either their nuclear arms or their conventional weapons.

context: A just government never restricts the right of its citizens to act upon their desires except when their acting upon their desires is a direct threat to the health or property of other of its citizens.
question: Explain why the judgment that a just government would not censor writings of Shakespeare, but it could censor magazines and movies that criticize the government does not closely conform to the principle cited above.
answer0: A just government would not censor magazines and movies that criticize the government because these things do not threaten the health or property of its citizens.
answer1: A government would not necessarily be unjust for incarcerating a citizen even though it had been several years since that citizen harmed someone since that person had been a threat to other citizens' health.
answer2: A just government would not ban the sale of sports cars because that would restrict he right of its citizens to act upon their desires but it could prohibit unrestricted racing because racing could be a direct threat to the health of other citizens.
answer3: It's unclear what kind of compulsory labor this would be therefore it's not clear whether the government would be unjust or not.

context: Over the past twenty-five years the introduction of laborsaving technologies has greatly reduced the average amount of time a worker needs to produce a given output, potentially both reducing the number of hours each worker works each week and increasing workers' leisure time correspondingly. The average amount of leisure time per worker, however, has increased at only half the rate at which the average hourly output per worker has grown.
question: What is the evidence that does not strongly support the claim that the average hourly output per worker has not risen as much as had been anticipated when modern labor-saving technologies were first introduced?
answer0: Leisure time and not a leisure budget is what has changed.
answer1: If the average weekly output per worker is higher now that 25 years ago, it must have grown.
answer2: There was no firm anticipation of average hourly output per worker.
answer3: A growth in the work force doesn't relate to output per worker.

context: The body of anyone infected by virus X will, after a week, produce antibodies to fight the virus; the antibodies will increase in number for the next year or so. There is now a test that reliably indicates how many antibodies are present in a person' s body. If positive, this test can be used during the first year of infection to estimate to within a month how long that person has had the virus.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that, if a person remains infected by virus X indefinitely, there is no limit to the number of antibodies that can be present in the person's body based on the statements above?
answer0: According to the passage, the antibodies will only increase for about a year after infection.
answer1: The antibodies increase for about a year, so one would expect the patient to be immune for about a year.
answer2: The antibodies begin to increase after a week, regardless of whether the virus has been defeated.
answer3: The production of antibodies is an automatic response to the viral infection.

main_question.question: Which one of the following conclusions is best supported by the statements above?
main_question.option: If a person remains infected by virus X indefinitely, there is no limit to the number of antibodies that can be present in the person's body.

context: It is proposed to allow the sale, without prescription, of a medication that physicians currently prescribe to treat the common ear inflammation called "swimmer' s ear. " The principal objection is that most people lack the expertise for proper self-diagnosis and might not seek medical help for more serious conditions in the mistaken belief that they have swimmer' s ear. Yet in a recent study, of 1, 000 people who suspected that they had swimmer' s ear, 84 percent had made a correct diagnosis -- a slightly better accuracy rate than physicians have in diagnosing swimmer' s ear. Thus, clearly, most people can diagnose swimmer' s ear in themselves without ever having to consult a physician.
question: What is the reason for the fact that many people who develop swimmer's ear having the condition disappear without medical or pharmaceutical intervention not undermining the conclusion?
answer0: The statement is not talking about ear specialists but physicians in general.
answer1: The progression does not have anything to do with diagnosis.
answer2: Having previous experience with the condition is a distinction between the people diagnosing themselves and most people.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: After an area has been hit by a natural disaster, there is often a great demand for plywood for repairing damaged homes. Retailers in the area often raise prices on new shipments of plywood to well above their predisaster prices, and some people denounce these retailers for taking advantage of a disaster to make more money on each sheet of plywood they sell. In fact, however, these retailers do not make more money on each sheet of plywood than before the disaster, because transporting the plywood into devastated areas is difficult and expensive, and ttherefore the plywood' s cost to retailers is higher than it was before the disaster.
question: Why is it valid to conclude that the argument depends on the assumption that the increase in the prices charged by retailers for plywood following a natural disaster does not exceed the increase in cost to those retailers?
answer0: It did not state the argument was inadequate.
answer1: The argument hinges on the idea that raising costs of plywood is not actually making more money than predisaster levels, if the increase prices exceeds the cost too much, it would imply the retailers are making more profits and make contradict the argument.
answer2: It rejected the argument on the arguer's actions not the opinion of those actions.
answer3: The passage states that the cost of transporting the plywood is more due to the challenges, so the argument does not depend on a lack of supply.

context: Ethicist: In a recent judicial decision, a woman was ordered to pay restitution to her husband because of their recent divorce, even though the couple had signed a written prenuptial agreement prior to getting married which stated that each party would be financially independent and not seek alimony should the couple decide to divorce. Thus, it was morally wrong for the man to change his mind and seek restitution.
question: Why does the fact that it is morally wrong for one party not to abide by its part of an agreement only if the other party abides by its part of the agreement not help to justify the ethicist's reasoning?
answer0: The husband is not penalizing the wife for signing a prenuptial agreement and is instead breaking the original agreement.
answer1: He states that the practice is annoying, not that people find it annoying. There is no reason given for why the mail is thrown out.
answer2: There was no mention of the other side of the argument. Only the argummnt that it is immoral was presented.
answer3: Whether or not the other party abides by its part of the agreement, the ethicist questions the morality of seeking restitution after agreeing in writing to not.

context: The principle of equality before the law rules out using media access and renown as valid considerations in the sentencing of convicted criminals. Nevertheless, movie stars found guilty of drug abuse in well-publicized trials are often sentenced to perform community service, while unknown defendants convicted of the same crimes usually serve prison sentences.
question: What evidence is there that the statements do not strongly support the conclusion that the principle of equality before the law can properly be overridden by other principles in some cases?
answer0: The passage focuses on why celebrities get lesser sentences not talking about principles being overridden.
answer1: The passage shows that it does allow for leniency making this conclusion wrong.
answer2: The example given in the passage supports this statement word for word.
answer3: The passage shows examples of how it is not being rigorously applied and criticizes this notion.

context: A tax preparation company automatically adds the following disclaimer to every e-mail message sent to its clients: "Any tax advice in this e-mail should not be construed as advocating any violation of the provisions of the tax code. " The only purpose this disclaimer could serve is to provide legal protection for the company. But if the e-mail elsewhere suggests that the client do something illegal, then the disclaimer offers no legal protection. So the disclaimer serves no purpose.
question: Why is it valid to conclude that the argument's conclusion can be properly drawn if it is assumed that if the e-mail does not elsewhere suggest that the client do anything illegal, then the company does not need legal protection?
answer0: The tax company wants to abide by the law so they make sure that they let the client know they do not condone illegal activity.
answer1: This is not known whether someone ignores or reads the disclaimers but the company wants their clients to know where they stand.
answer2: The company always needs legal protection and needs to make sure that the client is aware that they are not suggesting the client do anything illegal.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: A study of adults who suffer from migraine headaches revealed that a significant proportion of the study participants suffer from a complex syndrome characterized by a set of three symptoms. Those who suffer from the syndrome experienced excessive anxiety during early childhood. As adolescents, these people began experiencing migraine headaches. As these people approached the age of 20, they also began to experience recurring bouts of depression. Since this pattern is invariant, always with excessive anxiety at its beginning, it follows that excessive anxiety in childhood is one of the causes of migraine headaches and depression in later life.
question: Explain why the reasoning in the argument is not vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that it does not specify the proportion of those in the general population who suffer from the syndrome.
answer0: The exact number of people who suffer from these symptoms is not relevant to the argument being made.
answer1: If the company pays each employee based on the amount of work and intensity of work, then Pauline would be justified in expecting higher compensation.
answer2: Whether Lorraine agrees with Pauline's newer wage or not is irrelevant to what she deserves.

context: A survey was recently conducted among ferry passengers on the North Sea. Among the results was this: more of those who had taken anti-seasickness medication before their trip reported symptoms of seasickness than those who had not taken such medication. It is clear, then, that despite claims by drug companies that clinical tests show the contrary, people would be better off not taking anti-seasickness medications.
question: Why does the fact that given rough enough weather, most ferry passengers will have some symptoms of seasickness not weaken the conclusion?
answer0: Both parties responding to the survey ensures a balanced finding which does not weaken or strengthen the conclusion.
answer1: Being tested by the drug companies' staff should not have any influence on the reported seasickness results.
answer2: Most passengers experiencing seasickness should not result in a disproportionate number of people who took the medication reporting issues compared to those who didn't take the medication.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: A recent government study links the high rates of respiratory ailments in Groverston to airborne pollutants released by the Woodco plywood manufacturing plant there. To address the problem the government imposed strict regulations on emissions which will go into effect in four years. Although Woodco plans to cut its emissions in half two years ahead of schedule, it is unlikely that the rate of respiratory ailments will decline before the regulations go into effect, since __.
question: What is the reason for concluding that the statement that three new plywood manufacturing plants are about to go into production in Groverston logically completes the passage?
answer0: The number of facilities that treat respiratory ailments is not a factor in the Woodco emissions or emissions of other plywood plants.
answer1: Since new manufacturing plants are opening soon it logically follows that respiratory issues will continue to be an issue as the passage references a delay in the immediate implementation of regulations
answer2: Reduction of emissions is not related to production values at Woodco.
answer3: While this may be true in a vacuum, the passage refers to new laws going into effect and not long-term predictions.

context: During the period in which there are no competitive races, two runners--Runners A and Runners B--take part in an experiment measuring their VO2 max, the volume of oxygen an athlete can use. During these sessions, the runners engaged in moderate aerobic activity, or a sustained heart rate between 146-154 beats per minute. At the end of the sessions, Runner A had a greater VO2 max than did Runner B. Ttherefore, once the two runners begin identical intensive training--sessions involving over 168 beats per minute-- for the race season, Runner A will continue to have the greater VO2 max, assuming that neither become injured and that both train with similar intensity.
question: What is the reasoning for the argument not resting on the assumption that the amount one trains does not influence one's VO2 max?
answer0: This seems to be true in the passage, but is more of a supporting detail rather than the most supported detail.
answer1: This is not worded correctly. The amount is not the issue here. The intensity of training is the issue.
answer2: This is not a point of contention in the passage and who was influenced more by the other has no bearing on whether or not Stuart's work was influenced by West.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Although it is unwise to take a developmental view of an art like music -- as if Beethoven were an advance over Josquin, or Miles Davis an advance over Louis Armstrong -- there are ways in which it makes sense to talk about musical knowledge growing over time. We certainly know more about certain sounds than was known five centuries ago; that is, we understand how sounds that earlier composers avoided can be used effectively in musical compositions. For example, we now know how the interval of the third, which is considered dissonant, can be used in compositions to create consonant musical phrases.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that the main conclusion of the argument is that sounds that were once considered dissonant are more pleasing to modern listeners?
answer0: Dissonant sounds were only a small portion of the article's composition and not the main conclusion.
answer1: Although comparison of artist's is included, it is across arts and not the main conclusion of the article.
answer2: The article explicitly states that it makes sense to talk about musical knowledge growing over time.
answer3: While sounds not previously used in compositions being used in contemporary music is touched upon, it is not the main conclusion of the article.

We certainly know more about certain sounds than was known five centuries ago; that is, we understand how sounds that earlier composers avoided can be used effectively in musical compositions. For example, we now know how the interval of the third, which is considered dissonant, can be used in compositions to create consonant musical phrases.
main_question.question: Which one of the following most accurately expresses the main conclusion of the argument?
main_question.option: It is unwise to say that one composer is better than another.

context: Archaeologists excavating a Neanderthal campsite found discarded gazelle teeth there whose coloration indicated that gazelles had been hunted throughout the year. The archaeologists concluded that the Neanderthals had inhabited the campsite year-round and thus were not nomadic. In contrast, the archaeologists cite a neighboring campsite of nomadic Cro-Magnons that contained teeth from gazelles all killed during the same season.
question: Why does the fact that Cro-Magnons usually followed the migrations of the animals they hunted not seriously weaken the archaeologists' reasoning?
answer0: Evidence of trading is not evidence that either group was or wasn't nomadic.
answer1: If the school board increased the ratio of students to teachers, then there would be less of a shortage so the discrepancy in the world where they didn't increase the ratio wouldn't make sense.

context: One sure way you can tell how quickly a new idea -- for example, "globalization" -- is taking hold among the population is to monitor how fast the word or words expressing that particular idea are passing into common usage. context: On the basis of the available evidence, Antarctica has generally been thought to have been covered by ice for at least the past 14 million years. Recently, however, three-million-year-old fossils of a kind previously found only in ocean-floor sediments were discovered under the ice sheet covering central Antarctica. About three million years ago, ttherefore, the Antarctic ice sheet must temporarily have melted. After all, either severe climatic warming or volcanic activity in Antarctica' s mountains could have melted the ice sheet, thus raising sea levels and submerging the continent.

answer0: The conclusion pertains to the ice sheet, not the location of recently discovered remains.
answer1: We are not given this information in the passage and cannot simply assume that a neighborhood is qualified if it has construction occurring unless we are given information that excessive dirt is a result of the construction.
answer2: The author's conclusion is focused on the existence or extent of the ice sheet rather than the mechanism that may have caused changes in it.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Psychiatrist: In treating first-year students at this university, I have noticed that those reporting the highest levels of spending on recreation score at about the same level on standard screening instruments for anxiety and depression as those reporting the lowest levels of spending on recreation. This suggests that the first-year students with high levels of spending on recreation could reduce that spending without increasing their anxiety or depression.
question: Why does the fact that the screening instruments used by the psychiatrist are extremely accurate in revealing levels of anxiety and depression among university students not strengthen the psychiatrist's argument?
answer0: Confirmatory data from a comparable institution clearly strengthens the general argument being made about first year college students in general.
answer1: Highly accurate data is clearly more valuable than data of indeterminate accuracy, thus strengthening any argument based upon it.
answer2: Allowing managers to retire early is not relevant to the information in the passage regarding managers not suggesting staff reductions.
answer3: Unpredictable increases in workloads would be a reason not to suggest staff reduction as at anytime things could become much busier and a larger staff would be ideal.

context: The ruins of the prehistoric Bolivian city of Tiwanaku feature green andacite stones weighing up to 40 tons. These stones were quarried at Copacabana, which is across a lake and about 90 kilometers away. Archaeologists hypothesize that the stones were brought to Tiwanaku on reed boats. To show this was possible, experimenters transported a 9-ton stone from Copacabana to Tiwanaku using a reed boat built with locally available materials and techniques traditional to the area.
question: What evidence would be necessary to evaluate the support for the archaeologists' hypothesis regarding whether the traditional techniques for building reed boats were in use at the time Tiwanaku was inhabited?
answer0: The presence of even larger stones at Tiwanaku has no bearing on the transport of green andacite stones.
answer1: Green andacite stones usage on Copacabana has no bearing on its usage on Tiwanaku.
answer2: The reed boat needs to be durable enough to transfer the stones once.
answer3: Traditional techniques may have developed after the transport of green andacite stones, rendering the experiment irrelevant.

These stones were quarried at Copacabana, which is across a lake and about 90 kilometers away. Archaeologists hypothesize that the stones were brought to Tiwanaku on reed boats. To show this was possible, experimenters transported a 9-ton stone from Copacabana to Tiwanaku using a reed boat built with locally available materials and techniques traditional to the area.
main_question.question: Which one of the following would be most useful to know in order to evaluate the support for the archaeologists' hypothesis?
main_question.option: whether the reed boat built for the experimenters is durable enough to remain usable for several years

context: Editorial: To qualify as an effective law, as opposed to merely an impressive declaration, a command must be backed up by an effective enforcement mechanism. That is why societies have police. The power of the police to enforce a society' s laws makes those laws effective. But there is currently no international police force. Hence, what is called "international law" is not effective law.
question: Which of the following reasoning justifies that the editorial's argument does not require the assumption that the only difference between international law and the law of an individual society is the former's lack of an effective enforcement mechanism?
answer0: This statement has to be true for the argument to make sense, which means it’s necessary.
answer1: The argument never assumes that there aren’t other differences between international law and domestic law.
answer2: The conclusion suggested that an international police force was necessary, but never indicated that laws couldn’t still fail to be effective, even if there was a police force.
answer3: The argument doesn’t tell us whether there are other purposes or not.

context: The milk of many mammals contains cannabinoids, substances that are known to stimulate certain receptors in the brain. To investigate the function of cannabinoids, researchers injected newborn mice with a chemical that is known to block cannabinoids from reaching their receptors in the brain. The injected mice showed far less interest in feeding than normal newborn mice do. Ttherefore, cannabinoids probably function to stimulate the appetite.
question: What is the basis for the argument not depending on the assumption that newborn mice do not normally ingest any substance other than their mothers' milk?
answer0: The passage does not claim that newborn mice only ingest their mother's milk.
answer1: The passage makes not mention on how mother mice act around their young.
answer2: The passage assumes that the reason for less appetite is that cannabinoids aren't reaching the brain.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Very little is known about prehistoric hominid cave dwellers. However, a recent study of skeletons of these hominids has revealed an important clue about their daily activities: skeletal fractures present are most like the type and distribution of fractures sustained by rodeo riders. context: In a medical study of all of the residents of Groverhill, 35 people reported consulting their physician last year seeking relief from severe headaches. Those same physicians' records, however, indicate that 105 consultations occurred last year with Groverhill patients seeking relief from severe headaches. Obviously, then, many residents who consulted physicians for this condition did not remember doing so.
question: Why is the reasoning in the argument considered vulnerable to criticism for overlooking the possibility that residents of Groverhill visited their physicians more than once during the year for the same condition?
answer0: If there were residents who did suffer from severe headaches but did not consult their physician, this would reduce the number of consultations while increasing the number of reports instead of the other way around.
answer1: The passage does not make any claims regarding whether the number of residents in Groverhill having severe headaches is unusually high or not.
answer2: The source for the number of consultations comes from the physicians records of those residents who reported consulting their physician and does not imply that all those physicians were located in Groverhill.
answer3: If residents visited their physician more than once for severe headaches, this would increase the number of consultations without increasing the number of unique people consulting.

context: The Ixazyiquo tribe are believed to be one of the few remaining tribes in the country of Malugiato to have never had any contact with the Lamandians, settlers who arrived in Malugiain during the last hundred years. Using satellite imagery, a team of anthropologists determined that the Ixazyiquo land is covered with thriving banana plantations. The anthropologists conclude that the Ixazyiquo tribe has in fact had direct contact with the Lamandians.
question: How does the fact that maintaining banana plantations requires sophisticated knowledge that only the Lamadians possess support the anthropologists' conclusion?
answer0: The shape of the Ixazyiquo banana plantations is irrelevant to whether Lamandians have had direct contact with the Ixazyiquo, since there is no information given about how contact between the Ixazyiquo and Lamandians would influence the shapes of banana plantations.
answer1: If only Lamandians know how to maintain banana plantations, the presence of thriving banana plantations on Ixazyiquo land means that either there are Lamandians on Ixazyiquo land or that the Lamandians have provided this knowledge to the Ixazyiquo, both of which imply direct contact.
answer2: The Wamalami having direct contact with both the Ixazyiquo and the Lamandians does not imply that the Ixazyiquo and Lamandians have had direct contact with each other, and this contact is irrelevant to the presence of banana plantations on Ixazyiquo land.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: The faculty of Grey County Public Schools will shortly go on strike unless the school board increases their salary. As the school board president is well aware, however, in order to increase the faculty' s salary, Grey County Public Schools would have to cut some of its after-school programs. So, some of Grey County Public Schools' after-school programs will be cut.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that the conclusion is properly drawn if it is assumed that the school board will refuse to increase the faculty's salary?
answer0: If a salary increase does not take place then consequences for after-school programs that would arise from that increase would also not occur, contradicting the assertion in the argument.
answer1: The information is on those who have survived the heart attack. There would not be another heart attack after the first one if the person did not survive the heart attack.
answer2: The number of people who had a second heart attack would make no difference in the age of the first heart attack.
answer3: The authority to offer the increase is implicit in the assertion that cuts which would arise from the increase will occur, and does not need to be assumed.

context: Movie Director: Movies come out the best, in terms of both critical and box office success, when a single person has full creative control over the final product. Studios providing "notes" to the director, writer, producer, or whomever controls that vision, stifle the creative process. Studio Head: At the end of the day, the film industry is a business. Movies will only be made if they are profitable. The most successful movies focus on subjects that the audience cares about, and the studios spend millions of dollars on test screenings to determine what audiences prefer. Whether the studio transmits its research by "notes" or informal discussion, the studio' s input must be considered.
question: Why is it not accurate to describe the main point in dispute as being that critical acclaim is more important than box office success?
answer0: The debate is not over the method of communication but rather if that communication should occur at all or not.
answer1: The number of people involved is not in question but rather whether studio notes specifically have a negative impact on the success of a movie.
answer2: Critical claim is not being debated but rather how a movie is received by general audiences.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Some educators claim that it is best that school courses cover only basic subject matter, but cover it in depth. These educators argue that if students achieve a solid grasp of the basic concepts and investigatory techniques in a subject, they will be able to explore the breadth of that subject on their own after the course is over. But if they simply learn a lot of factual information, without truly understanding its significance, they will not be well equipped for further study on their own.
question: What is the basis for accepting the statement that it is easier to understand any Greek tragedy after one has analyzed a few of them in detail based on the educators' reasoning?
answer0: If B. t. toxins are quickly resisted and rendered ineffective, chemical insecticides are preferable.
answer1: B. t. toxins are used to control insects and its effect on weeds isn't a consideration.
answer2: Studying several Greek tragedies in detail in order to provide a better understanding of them is in line with the author's reasoning that limited in depth studies are superior to a multitude of surface level examinations.
answer3: How easily plant and animals are classified is not necessarily related to the passage's support for in depth study of fewer subjects.

context: Mystery stories often feature a brilliant detective and the detective' s dull companion. Clues are presented in the story, and the companion wrongly infers an inaccurate solution to the mystery using the same clues that the detective uses to deduce the correct solution. Thus, the author' s strategy of including the dull companion gives readers a chance to solve the mystery while also diverting them from the correct solution.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that most mystery stories feature a brilliant detective who solves the mystery presented in the story based on the information provided?
answer0: The passage refers to the common trope of there being a brilliant detective and a dull companion, this does not mean that most mystery stories in general in the entire genre feature a brilliant detective.
answer1: While it may be possible that readers spot the errors of the dull companion, this is not stated in the passage and any number of strategies could explain how readers come to the correct solution.
answer2: The passage states that clues are provided in the stories such that a dull compassion and a brilliant detective solve them incorrectly and correctly respectively with the same information, which the reader can play along with, so a brilliant reader may be able to infer the correct solution just like the brilliant detective.
answer3: The passage implies that the clues used by both the companion and the detective are the same, but the dull companion pieces them together incorrectly, not that they use incorrect or different clues.

main_question.context: Mystery stories often feature a brilliant detective and the detective' s dull companion. Clues are presented in the story, and the companion wrongly infers an inaccurate solution to the mystery using the same clues that the detective uses to deduce the correct solution. Thus, the author' s strategy of including the dull companion gives readers a chance to solve the mystery while also diverting them from the correct solution.
main_question.question: Which one of the following is most strongly supported by the information above?
main_question.option: Most mystery stories feature a brilliant detective who solves the mystery presented in the story.

context: Seemingly inconsequential changes in sea temperature due to global warming eventually result in declines in fish and seabird populations. A rise of just two degrees prevents the vertical mixing of seawater from different strata. This restricts the availability of upwelling nutrients to phytoplankton. Since zooplankton, which feed upon phytoplankton, feed the rest of the food chain, the declines are inevitable.
question: How does the statement that zooplankton feed upon phytoplankton help demonstrate how global temperature changes affect larger sea animals indirectly?
answer0: The relation between zooplankton and phytoplankton is not merely used to show that feeding habits change, but that these changes will have effects throughout the entire chain and will thus affect larger sea animals.
answer1: The relation between zooplankton and phytoplankton is linked to how they feed the rest of the food chain, and thus how larger animals will be affected as they are part of that chain.
answer2: The relation between zooplankton and phytoplankton is not meant to argue whether or not global warming should be curtailed, but merely to illustrate the effects global warming will have.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: We ought to pay attention only to the intrinsic properties of a work of art. Its other, extrinsic properties are irrelevant to our aesthetic interactions with it. For example, when we look at a painting we should consider only what is directly presented in our experience of it. What is really aesthetically relevant, ttherefore, is not what a painting symbolizes, but what it directly presents to experience.

context: Any organization must consider changing its basic structure if there is a dramatic change in its size. Doubling or tripling in size can lead to inefficiency and mismanagement, which restructuring often alleviates. Experience further shows that the more dramatic the change in size, the more fundamental the restructuring needs to be. Ttherefore, any organization must consider changing its basic structure once it is 20 years old.
question: Why does the argument's conclusion not follow logically even if it is assumed that no organization that has remained the same size for 20 years is efficient?
answer0: No assumptions were made based on an organization remaining the same size for any period of time.
answer1: Assuming organizations have not changed in size does not follow the conclusion claiming organizations need to change after 20 years.
answer2: Being more efficient after a restructure is already assumed and does not explain the 20 year time limit.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: The crux of creativity resides in the ability to manufacture variation on a theme. If we look at the history of science, for instance, we see that every idea is built upon a thousand related ideas. Careful analysis leads us to understand that what we choose to call a new theme or a new discovery is itself always and without exception some sort of variation, on a deep level, of previous themes.
question: Why does careful analysis of a specific variation not have to reveal previous themes of which it is a variation?
answer0: This statement directly contradicts what the passage is concluding, therefore it cannot be true.
answer1: The passage says that everything is based on previous themes which provides support for this claim
answer2: This statement just reiterates what the passage is stating
answer3: None of the above choices

context: A recent study suggests that consuming three glasses of wine daily substantially decreases the risk of stroke. Critics of the study, defending earlier research recommending one glass of wine daily, claim that binge drinkers (who drink once a week or less, but drink three or more drinks when they do drink) are the people most likely to drink three glasses of wine in one day and are more likely to die from sudden heart attacks than are other drinkers. According to these critics, drinking three glasses of wine daily would not benefit health overall, since the decrease in the risk of stroke associated with that level of consumption is negated by its associated increased risk of sudden heart attack.
question: Why is the critics' argument not considered to be flawed for assuming, without evidence, that there is no significant difference between wine and other alcoholic beverages in terms of health benefits and risks?
answer0: The passage does not show confusion, it is pretty clear that they are talking only about sudden alcohol related heart attacks, there is not question about that.
answer1: There is no way to know whether the people that would stick to the three glasses of wine method would drink more than this or be a binge drinker.
answer2: The article mentions that wine could have the benefit, it does not mention the benefits of other alcoholic substances.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Human rights activists have urged consumers to be conscious of the labor practices employed by manufacturers, especially in developing nations, saying that if we accept moral responsibility for our impact on third world workers, we must buy products from manufacturers that do not take advantage of their workers. It is nearly impossible, however, to determine which manufacturers are employing fair labor practices. Because of this impossibility there can be no moral obligation to choose products in the way these activists urge, because__.
question: Explain why the principle that a moral choice is more important than a moral action does not provide the appropriate completion for the argument.
answer0: What is relevant to the argument is the outcome for the children, not the potential causes.
answer1: If a moral choice is more important then it should be a moral obligation to make one irrespective of whether the consequent action can be known to be moral.
answer2: No mention of the amount of effort involved in making moral choices or actions is made by the argument.
answer3: Alan's argument has no basis in appealing to those in power.

context: Astronomers have found new evidence that the number of galaxies in the universe is not 10 billion, as previously believed, but 50 billion. This discovery will have an important effect on theories about how galaxies are formed. But even though astronomers now believe 40 billion more galaxies exist, many astronomers' estimates of the universe' s total mass remain virtually unchanged.
question: Why does the fact that the overwhelming majority of galaxies are so far from Earth that their mass can be only roughly estimated not explain why the estimates remain virtually unchanged?
answer0: Galaxies being so far that they can only be roughly estimated would not explain why such a drastic reduction in the number of galaxies would not leave to a rough estimation that reduces the total mass of the universe.
answer1: Even if there was no consensus on how to estimate the universe's mass, whatever current methods would have to be applied and there would sensibly be a reduction in that estimate given such a drastic reduction in the number of galaxies.
answer2: If galaxies make up an insignificant portion of the galaxy's total mass, then a severe reduction in the amount of galaxies would not significantly change the total mass of the galaxy.
answer3: There potentially being more galaxies to be found in the future with better instruments doesn't explain why the current estimate of the mass of the universe did not change along with the change in the number of galaxies.

context: Veterinarian: A disease of purebred racehorses that is caused by a genetic defect prevents afflicted horses from racing and can cause paralysis and death. Some horse breeders conclude that because the disease can have such serious consequences, horses with this defect should not be bred. But they are wrong because, in most cases, the severity of the disease can be controlled by diet and medication, and the defect also produces horses of extreme beauty that are in great demand in the horse show industry.
question: Why does the veterinarian's response to the horse breeders not accurately reflect the point that racehorses that have the genetic defect need not be prevented from racing?
answer0: This is probably true but the main point of the passage is the vet's opposition to the breeding ban not just preventing of the horses from racing.
answer1: The veterinarian argues that the genetic defect may not be serious as it can be treated with diet and medication. Besides, the vet also claims that defect may be a good thing in the show industry. Therefore the vet's stand is against an absolute ban.
answer2: This is not provided in the passage. It could be true or false but whether the horses have been treated with a diet is not the main point of the vet's argument.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: PhishCo runs a number of farms in the arid province of Nufa, depending largely on irrigation. Now, as part of a plan to efficiently increase the farms' total production, it plans to drill down to an aquifer containing warm, slightly salty water that will be used to raise fish in ponds. The water from the ponds will later be used to supplement piped-in irrigation water for PhishCo's vegetable fields, and the ponds and accompanying vegetation should help reduce the heat in the area of the farms.
question: Why does the fact that fish raised on PhishCo's farms are likely to be saleable in the nearest urban areas not strongly suggest that the plan, if implemented, would increase the overall efficiency of PhishCo's farms?
answer0: The potential for profit has no bearing on the efficiency of how the farm is run.
answer1: Ponds on low-lying lands would make it harder to move the water to the fields, and they would prevent the farmers would have to replant the grain that was usually in that area.
answer2: Rather than having to buy and apply fertilizer, the farmers could rely on the fish pond to produce enough fertilizer that would be distributed across the fields at the same time as the water.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Some government economists view their home countries as immune to outside influence. But economies are always open systems; international trade significantly affects prices and wages. Just as physicists learned the shortcomings of a mechanics based on idealizations such as the postulation of perfectly frictionless bodies, government economists must look beyond national borders if their nations' economies are to prosper.
question: Why does the argument's conclusion not follow logically even if it is assumed that some government economists have been ignoring the effects of international trade on prices and wages?
answer0: Prices and wages are merely one part of an economic picture and does not apply as it is not a holistic view of the situation.
answer1: Because the argument is about the overall level of funding decreasing, it must rely on the assumption that the increased government funding won't outweigh the reduction in private funding.
answer2: Whether the majority of funding should come from the government or not isn't relevant to an argument about what would cause an absolute decrease in private donations.
answer3: The accuracy of economic theories are not called into question only the method by which the theories are generated.

context: Consumer advocate: Ephedra is a naturally occurring compound that some people use as a weight-loss aid. context: Editorial: A proposed new law would limit elementary school class sizes to a maximum of 20 students. Most parents support this measure and argue that making classes smaller allows teachers to devote more time to each student, with the result that students become more engaged in the learning process. However, researchers who conducted a recent study conclude from their results that this reasoning is questionable. The researchers studied schools that had undergone recent reductions in class size, and found that despite an increase in the amount of time teachers spent individually with students, the students' average grades were unchanged.
question: Why does the researchers' argument not require the assumption that the only schools appropriate for study are large elementary schools?
answer0: The researchers make an argument about the value of increased student engagement based solely on evidence from average grades, and so a causal relationship between the two is a necessary assumption of the argument.
answer1: The argument concerns only the validity of one particular reason cited for supporting the law; it does not require that this be the only reason to do so.
answer2: The argument makes no mention of the size or type of school studied by the researchers.
answer3: The argument concerns average grades across all the teacher's students, and so the proportion of their time devoted to each student is not relevant.

context: Certain companies require their managers to rank workers in the groups they supervise from best to worst, giving each worker a unique ranking based on job performance. The top 10 percent of the workers in each group are rewarded and the bottom 10 percent are penalized or fired. But this system is unfair to workers. Good workers could receive low rankings merely because they belong to groups of exceptionally good workers. Furthermore, managers often give the highest rankings to workers who share the manager' s interests outside of work.
question: Explain why the conclusion does not accurately express that under the ranking system, the top 10 percent of the workers in each group are rewarded and the bottom 10 percent are penalized or fired?
answer0: If alcohol-related traffic deaths among people under 21 have decreased, but the amount of drinking has been the same, then the number of people under 21 driving after drinking has decreased.
answer1: As it is possible for workers to receive low rankings if they are grouped with similarly exceptional workers, the ranking system is not a fair way to determine penalties or rewards.
answer2: That the top ten percent would be rewarded and the bottom ten percent penalized or fired is a premise, as it is already decided on by the company.
answer3: More people under 21 who own a car would is more likely to increase traffic deaths than reduce them.

context: Lawyer: In a risky surgical procedure that is performed only with the patient' s informed consent, doctors intentionally cause the patient' s heart and brain functions to stop by drastically reducing the patient' s body temperature. When the procedure is completed, body temperature is quickly restored. Because the doctors deliberately stop the patient' s life functions, if these functions do not resume following the procedure, the medical team is technically guilty of manslaughter.
question: How does the principle that deliberately bringing about the cessation of a person's life functions is manslaughter if and only if the cessation is permanent help to justify the lawyer's analysis?
answer0: Events that are scheduled years and advance would have time to adjust to a new schedule.
answer1: If the cessation is permanent, the procedure ends up being a permanent deliberate way of stopping the patient's life functions, making it manslaughter.
answer2: The temporary cessation of life functions to later restore them is not an intention to cause irreversible loss of those functions.
answer3: Employed people could adjust their schedules to celebrate weekend holidays on the work days before or after the weekend to accomodate.

context: A naturally occurring deposit of radioactive material similar in composition to the dangerous waste produced by applications of nuclear technology has been found deep within the Earth' s crust. No ill effects have been traced to this naturally occurring deposit. Since engineers have now developed a way to store manufactured nuclear waste as deeply within the Earth' s crust as the recently found natural radioactive deposit, the safe disposal of nuclear waste can now be initiated.
question: Explain why the fact that continued production of nuclear waste at the current rate will eventually outstrip available capacity for safe storage does not seriously weaken the argument.
answer0: The passage is stating that there already exists a radioactive deposit similar in composition to the nuclear waste being produced and so the current methods used to dispose of nuclear waste are not being discussed or called into question. Rather, the passage is suggesting adding our nuclear waste alongside the naturally occurring radioactive deposits deep in the earth.
answer1: Without knowing the geological conditions under which the naturally occurring radioactive deposit has been apparently safely contained, the added nuclear waste could disrupt this causing the naturally occurring radioactive deposit and the nuclear waste to no longer be safely contained.
answer2: If the total amount of nuclear waste produced annually has been declining, this would potentially help strengthen the argument that safe disposal can be initiated
answer3: The concern seems to be whether safe disposal can be initiated, not whether the capacity for safe storage will be inadequate to contain nuclear waste if production continues at the current rate.

context: The official listing of an animal species as endangered triggers the enforcement of legal safeguards designed to protect endangered species, such as tighter animal export and trade restrictions and stronger antipoaching laws. Nevertheless, there have been many cases in which the decline in the wild population of a species was more rapid after that species was listed as endangered than before it was so listed.
question: What is the reason for why public campaigns to save endangered animal species often focusing only on those species that garner the public's affection does not account for the increase in the rate of population decline described above?
answer0: The passage is discussing what happens after the animal is already placed on the endangered list, so the animals that don't become part of a public campaign are not relevant.
answer1: The article is concerned with what happens after the animal has already made it to the endangered list, not what happens while its placement on the list is being processed.
answer2: Collectors and poachers might go after the animals more once they believe that their species will soon die out. That will cause more of the animals to be killed.
answer3: If the poachers were finding it difficult to locate the animals, that would only protect them from being killed and help preserve their numbers.

context: A mass of "black water" containing noxious organic material swept through Laurel Bay last year. Some scientists believe that this event was a naturally occurring but infrequent phenomenon. The black water completely wiped out five species of coral in the bay, including mounds of coral that were more than two centuries old. Ttherefore, even if this black water phenomenon has struck the bay before, it did not reach last year' s intensity at any time in the past two centuries.
question: What is the reasoning for why the argument does not require the assumption that every species of coral in the bay was seriously harmed by the mass of black water that swept in last year?
answer0: If the mounds of centuries-old coral were strong and healthy before the "black water" mass, they may very well be a connection to their destruction, after the "black water" mass recently.
answer1: The level of vulnerability of the coral, older or younger, may or may not fluctuate, comparatively.
answer2: Five species of coral have been discussed, although a global generalization for all coral in the bay, has not been asserted.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.option: Every species of coral in the bay was seriously harmed by the mass of black water that swept in last year.

context: Psychotherapy has been described as a form of moral coercion. However, when people are coerced, their ability to make choices is restricted, and the goal of psychotherapy is to enhance people' s ability to make choices. Hence, psychotherapy cannot possibly be a form of coercion.
question: Explain why the fact that the goals of psychotherapy are taken to justify any means that are used to achieve those goals does not constitute a flaw in the argument.
answer0: Whether or not there is a single goal or many complex goals is irrelevant to the criticism that it is a form of moral coercion.
answer1: The goal of enhancing the ability to make choices is not trying to justify the means of restricting people's choices.
answer2: If it were possible for the practice or results of psychotherapy to run counter to it's own goals, then it does not enhance their ability to make choices and only restricts it, making it a form of moral coercion.
answer3: The desirability of moral coercion has no impact on whether or not moral coercion is taking place as a result of psychotherapy.

context: Demand levels for some categories of products are closely interdependent. When one type of a product can serve as a complement for another product, the levels of demand for these goods are positively related. An increase in the demand for one product usually increases the demand for its complementary product. Similarly, a decrease in the demand for one good causes a decrease in the demand for its complementary product.
question: How does the statement that a decrease in the demand for CD players results in a decrease in the demand for CD's illustrate the relationship between product demands described above?
answer0: Toothpaste and cellular phones are not interdependent. Demand for toothpaste may increase for reasons unrelated to cellular phone demand.
answer1: Butter and margarine do the same task, and are competitive,  rather than interdependent.
answer2: As the technology of CD players was replaced with newer technology, these were no longer needed, and thus the CDs themselves, were also no longer needed, as online purchase options are more available.
answer3: A decrease in cable television may be caused by competitive options, such as streaming internet services like Netflix. Satellite antennas are not interdependent on cable television demands.

main_question.context: Demand levels for some categories of products are closely interdependent. An increase in the demand for one product usually increases the demand for its complementary product. Similarly, a decrease in the demand for one good causes a decrease in the demand for its complementary product.

context: High-technology medicine is driving up the nation' s health care costs. Recent advances in cataract surgery illustrate why this is occurring. Cataracts are a major cause of blindness, especially in elderly people. Ten years ago, cataract surgery was painful and not always effective. Thanks to the new technology used in cataract surgery, the operation now restores vision dramatically and is less expensive. These two factors have caused the number of cataract operations performed to increase greatly, which has, in turn, driven up the total amount spent on cataract surgery.
question: Why is it not valid to infer from the passage that ten years ago, cataract surgery was affordable for more people than it was last year?
answer0: This does not support the argument of the government offering incentives as the passage is not focused upon other countries and their efficiency compared to ours, only at improving our own.
answer1: Which of these issues is a greater problem does not effect the argument that the government should provide incentives to the companies.
answer2: The passage explicitly states that cataract surgery has become less expensive over the last ten years, which would actually make it affordable for more people.
answer3: As the argument explicitly states that overall cataract surgery costs have increased whilst an individual cataract operation's costs have decreased, then an increase in the number of operations is the most likely cause of that overall increase.

Cataracts are a major cause of blindness, especially in elderly people. Ten years ago, cataract surgery was painful and not always effective. Thanks to the new technology used in cataract surgery, the operation now restores vision dramatically and is less expensive. These two factors have caused the number of cataract operations performed to increase greatly, which has, in turn, driven up the total amount spent on cataract surgery.
main_question.question: Which one of the following can be inferred from the passage?
main_question.option: Ten years ago, few people had successful cataract surgery.
